Lucan, lib. 6. quem nod●sque nocentes ore suo rupit, pend●ntia corpor a carpsit abrasitque cruces percusaque viscera nimbis v●list & incoctas admisso sole medullas, insertum 〈…〉, nigramque per artus stillantis tabi saniem virusque coactum sustulit & morsus nervo retinente pependi●.
For the use of dead bodies in Witchcraft see
Apuleius, De aureo 〈◊〉, lib. 3.
speaking of
〈◊〉 Priusque apparatu solito instruxit feralem officinam.
Among other things
, Sepultorum cadaverum expositis mul●is admodum●●membris hic nares illic digiti, illic carnosi clavi pendentium, alibi trucidatorum 〈…〉
From a Murdrer that hung in Chains
I bit dryd Sinews and shrunk Veins.
Marrow and Entrails I have Brought,
A piece ot'h' Gibbet too I got,
And of the Rope the fatal Knot.
I sunk a Ship, and in my flight
I kickt a Steeple down to Night.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Well done my Dame, Ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l:
i
i Lucan
makes his Witch inhabit such places,
Desertaque busta incolit & 〈◊〉 ob●inet umbris. Agrippa de occulta Philosophia, lib. 1. cap. 48. Saturno correspondent 〈◊〉 fetida tenebrosa s●bterranea religiosa funesta ut coemiteria busta & hominibus deserta habitacula & vetustate caduca loca obscura & horrenda & solitaria astra, cavernae, pu●ei, &c.
And in his third Book
, cap. 42. Aptissima loca plurim●m experientia visionum nocturnalium incur●ionum & consimilium phantasinatum ut c●miteria & in quibus fieri solent executiones criminalis judicij, &c.
To Gibbets I flew and dismal Caves,
To Charnel houses and to Graves.

k
k Lucan, lib. 6. Ast. Vbi servantur saxis, quibus intiums humor d●citur, & tra●ta durescunt●a medu●●e cor● ora tunc omnes avide des●●vit in artus immersitque meanus oculis, gaudetque gelatos aeffodisse orbes.
Bones I got, and flesh enough
From dead mens Eyes the glewy●Stuff,
Their Eye-balls with my nailes scoop'd out
And pieces of their Limbs I've brought—

l
l Nider in his Formicarlum mentions one that kill'd Seven Children in the Mothers Womb, by Witchcraft: This, he says, was done by laying ● Lizard under the Threshold, and that will cause abortion in every Female in the House:
Vide Form ●ar. cap. 3. Remigius
says about the Cocks-crowing, that nothing is so hateful to the Witches when they are at their Charms, as the Cock-crowing; as one Latoma a Witch, among other things confessed; and several other Authors mention, it as very hateful to the Witches.
A Brat ith Mothers Womb I slew.
The Fathers neck I Twisted too.
Doggs-barkt, Cocks-Crowed, away I flew.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: A good Servant, Ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Harg.
sp.l:
m
m for. Epod. 5. amongst Canidias
materialls reckons
, Ossa ab ore rapta jejunae Canis. And Lucan▪ lib. 6. of Erictho. Et quodcunque jacet nuda tellure cadaver ante feras vulucresque sedet; nec carper● membra vult ferro manibusque suis morsusque luporum expectat siccis raptura a faucibus artus.
Flesh from a Raven in a Ditch
I snatcht, and more from a ravenous Bitch.

n
n See Apuleius before cited,
Mongst Tombs I search'd for flesh and bore,

o
o ● Ovid per tumulos errat sparsis distincta Capillis.
See the Notes of the third Act.
With hair about my ears alone.

p
p For the parts of the Body, the Wen and the blood of slain men, See Apuleius before quoted.
Fingers, Noses, and a Wen.
And the blood of murder'd men,

q
q Lucan, lib. 6. Huc quicquid foetu genuit natura sinistro miscetur: Non spuma canum quibus unda timori est viscera non Lyncis non durae nodus Hyaenae defuit.
A mad Dogs Foam, and a Wolves Hairs,
A Serpents Bowels, Adders Ears,
I put in my Pou●ch; and coming back
The Bells in a Steeple I did crack.
I sent the murren into Hogs,
And drove the Kine into the Bogs.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Tis well, 'tis well. Ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.l:
r
r For Philtres, See Iuvenal. Sat. 6. Hic Magicos afbert cantus hic Thessala vendit Philtra.
To make up Love Cups I have sought,
A Wolfs Tail, Hair, and Yard, I've got
The Green Frogs Bones, whose flesh was tain
From thence by Ants; then a Cats Brain,
The Bunch of flesh from a black Foles head,
Just as his Dam was brought to Bed,
Before she lickt it; and I have some
Of that which falls from a Mares Womb
When she's in Lust; and as I came home
I put a woman into ●its
And frighted a Parson out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: All's well. Ho, ho, ho, ho.

lg.l: WHat joy like ours can mortals find?
We can command the Sea and Wind:
All Elements our Charms obey,
And all good things become our prey;
The daintiest Meat, and lustiest Wine,
We for our Sabaths still design.
'Mongst all the great Princes the sun shall ere see.
None can be so great, or so happy as we.
We Sail in Egg-shells on rough Seas,
And se● strange 〈◊〉 when we please▪
Or on our Be●soms we can fly,
And nimbly mounting to the Sky,
We leave the swiftest Birds behind,
And when we please outstrip the Wind:
Then we feast and we revel after long ●light,
Or with a Lov'd Incubus sport all the night.
When we're on Wing, we sport and play,
Mankind, like Emmets, we survey;
With Lightening blast with Thunder Kill.
Cause barrennesss where e're we will.
Of full revenge we have the power;
And Heaven it self can have no more.
Heres a health to our Master the Prince of the Flies,
Who commands from Center all up to the Skies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
s
s
For this following potion, take the Words of
Wierus de praestig. Daem, lib. 3. cap. 37. Inter amatoria ad haec venena connumerant●●, in extrema lupi cauda pilus, ejusque virga, remora pis●iculus, selis cerebrum & Lacertae stellio cui, stincus nomen est item ●s de rana ●●ridi in formicarum acervo exesa: See Pliny, lib. 8. cap. 22.
Harr,
t
t This Hyppomanes Pliny in Nat. Hist. And Aristotle de Nat. 〈◊〉
mentions, and all the old Poets,
Virg, Aeneid, 4. Quaeritur, & 〈◊〉 equi de fronte 〈◊〉 & matu praeceptusamor.
See this discribed
in Wierus, lib. 3. cap. 37. Ovid, lib. 2. De arte Amandi datque quod a teueri fronte revellit equi. Lucan, lib. 6. Nec noxia tantum pocula proficiunt, aut quum furgentio succo frontis amaturae subducunt pignora faetae.
harr,
u
u Virg. 3. Georg. Hinc demum hyppomanes ve●o quod nomine dicunt Pastores, Lentum distillat ab inguine virus. Tibul●●, lib. 1. El●g. 4. Hippamanes cupidae stillat ab inguine Equae, Ovid, lib. 1. Eleg. 8.
Upon a Bawd
, Seu bene quid gramen quid torto concita rhomb● Licia quid valeat virus amantis equae propert, lib. 4. (in quandam Laenam Consuluit strigas nostro de sanguine & in me hippomanes faetae semina legit aeque. In Wier● it is thus described, Caruncula band parum famora, caricae magnitudine specie orbiculata, Latiuscula, colore nigro, quae in fronte nascentis pulli equini apparet, quam edito statim partu mater lambendo, abstergendoque dev●eat & si praeripiatur animum a faetu peni●us aversum habet nee eum ad ubera admit●t.
That they make these confused noises, see
Nandaeus, Hist, Mag. & Pet. de Loyer de Spectris.
And that these shouts and these words and are used by them, see
Scott. p. 42. and Bodin, lib. 2. cap. 4. This is to be found in Remigius, and Delrio, and M. Phi. Lud●●igus Elich
out of them says
, quest. 10. Tota turba 〈…〉.
Harr, harr, harr, hoo, hoo, hoo, sabath, sabath, sabath, Devil, Devil, Devil, dance here, dance there, play here, play there, harr, harr, harr, hoo, hoo, hoo.—

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage:
Enter Sir
Edward Harfort, Bellfort and Doubty.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: YOu have extreamly delighted us this morning, by your House, Gardens, your Accommodation, and your way of Living, you put me in mind of the renowned Sidneys Admirable description of Kalandar.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Sir you Complement me too much.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Methinks you represent to us the Golden days of Queen Elizabeth, such sure were our Gentry then; now they are grown Servile Apes to Forreign customes, they leave off Hospitality, for which we were famous all over Europe, and turn Servants to Board-wages.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: For my part, I love to have my Servants part of my Family, the other were to hire day Labourers to wait on me, I had rather my Friends, Kindred, Tennants and Servants should live well out of me, than Coach-makers, Taylors, Embroiderers, and Lacemen should: To be pointed at in the Streets, and have Fools stare at my Equipage, is a vanity I have always scorn'd.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: You speak like one descended from those Noble Ancestors that made France tremble, and all the rest of Europe Honour 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I reverence the Memory of 'em: But our New-fashion'd Gentry love the French too well to fight against 'em; they are bred abroad without knowing any thing of our Constitution, and come home tainted with Foppery, slavish Principles, and Popish Religion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They bring home Arts of Building from hot Countries to serve for our cold one; and F●●gality from those places where they have little Meat and small Stomacks, to suffice us who have great plenty and lusty Appetites.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: They build Houses with Halls in 'em, not so big as former Porches; Beggars were better entertained by their Ancestors, than their Tennants by them.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: For my part, I think 'twas never good days, but when great Tables were kept in large Halls; the Buttery-hatch always open, Black Jacks, and a good smell of Meat and March-beer, with Dogs-turds, and Mary-bones as Ornaments in the Hall: These were signs of good House keeping, I hate to see Italian fine Buildings with no Meat or Drink in 'em▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I like not their little Plates, methinks there's Vertue in an English Sur-loyn.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Our Sparks bring nothing but Forreign Vices and Follies home; 'tis rediculous to be bred in one Country to learn to live in another.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: While we lived thus (to borrow a Coxcombly word) we made a better Figure in the World.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You have a mind that suits your Fortune, and can make your own happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
The greatest is the Enjoyment of my Friends, and such Worthy Gentlemen
●s your Selves, and when I cannot have enough of that; I have a Library, good Horses and good Musick.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Princes may envy such an English Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
You are too kind
, I am a true English man, I love the Princes Rights and P●ples liberties, and will defend 'em both with the last penny in my purse, and the last drop in my veins, and dare defy the witless Plots of Papists.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Spoken like a Noble Patriot.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Pardon me, you talk like English-men, and you have warm'd me; I hope to see the Prince and People flourish yet; old as I am, inspite of Jesuits, I am sure our Constitution is the Noblest in the World.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Would there were enough such English Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Twere to be wisht; but our Gentry are so much poysoned with Forreign Vanities, that methinks the Genius of England seems sunk into the Yeoma●●y.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: We have indeed too many rotten Members▪ You speak like Gentlemen, Worthy of such Noble Fathers, as you both had; but Gentlemen I spoke of Musick, I see two of my Artists, come into the Garden, they shall entertain you with a Song this Morning.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir you oblige us every way.
Finely compos'd, and excellently perform'd.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I see Sir you are well serv'd in every thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: My sweet Cousin good Morrow to thee, I hope to call thee shortly by another Name, my dear Child, Heaven's bless thee▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ladies your most humble Servant; you are early up to take the pleasure of the Morning in these Gardens.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: 'Tis a Paradice you are in; every object within this place is ravishing.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: This place affords variety of Pleasures; nothing here is wanting.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Where such fine Ladies are.

div.stage:
Enter Servant with
Tegue O Devilly
an Irish-Priest.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A Gentleman, To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: With me! Daughter pray shew those Gentlemen the Statues, Grottoes and the Water-works, I●le wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is an opportunity beyond our hopes.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Arrah, and please ty Oorship, I am come here to displaash to maake a 〈◊〉 unto thee, dest dou not know me Joy?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Oh! You live at Mr. Redletters my Catholick Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Ah by my Shoul, I.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: How came you to venture hither? you are a Popish-Priest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Ay, but 'tis no matter for all daat ●oy: by my Shoul, but I vill taak de
Oades, and I think I vill be excus'd, but hark 〈◊〉 you a while, by my trott I shall be a Paapist too for all daat, indeed, yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Excellent Principles.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I do come for de nonest to see dee, and yet I do not come on purpose gra: But it is no matter, I will talk vid you about daat, I do come upon occaasion and Mr. Redletter did shend me unto de●.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: For What?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: What will I say unto dee now, but Mr. Redletter did shend me, and yet I did come of my self too for all daat upon occaasion, daat I did heare, concerning of dee, dat dy House and de Plaash is all over-run with Witches and Spirits, do you see now?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I had best let this Fool stay to laugh at him, he may be out of the damn'd Plot, if any Priest was? Sure they would never trust this Fool.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: What shaall you shay unto me upon all dis, I will exorcize doze Vitches, and I will plague dose Devils now by my Shoul, vid Holy-Water, and vid Reliques, and I will ●reet 'em out of his Plaash, God shaave the King.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I have forgot your Name.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: They do put the Name of Kelly upon me, Joy, but by my fait I am call'd by my own right Name, Tegue O Devilly.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Tegue O Devilly?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Yes, a very oold Naam in Eereland by my Shalvaation, well gra, I have brought upon my Cloke-bagg shome Holy-water, and I will put it upon the Devils and de Vitches Faashes, and I will make you shome more Holy-water, and you will vaash all de Roomes vid it and bee—

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Well, Father Tegue O Devilly, You're welcom; but how ●are you venture publickly in these times?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Why, I have great consideraation upon dy Prudence; for if dou woudst betray me, now phare will be de soleedity of dat Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I speak not for my self, but others.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: The Devil ●aak me now, I do think, I will suffer for my Religion, I am affraid I will be slain at lasht at the plaash they call Saint Ty-burn, but I do not caare by my Shalvaation; for if I will be hang'd, I will be a Saint presently, and all my Country shall pray unto Saint Tegue, besides, shome great people will be naamless too, I tell you I shay noe more, but I will be prayed unto Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Prayed too! Very well.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Yes by my Shoule will I, and I will have Reliques maade of me too.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Sir
Ieffery Shacklehead
and my Lady have some business with you, and desire your company within.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Come Father Tegue, come along with me, do you hear, find the Gentlemen that are walking with my Daughter and her Couzen, and tell 'em I will wait on 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
I will. They are here, Gentlemen, my Master is called away upon business
〈◊〉 begs your excuse, and will wait on you presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Heaven gives us yet a longer Opportunity, and certainly intends we should make use of it; I have my own Parson that comes to hunt with me at Whally, Madam, an excellent School Divine, that will end all differences betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: He is like to begin 'em betwixt us▪ the Name of a Parson is a dreadful Name upon these occasions, he I bring us into a Condition we can never get out of but by Death.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If the absolute command of me and my Fortune can please you, you shall never desire to get out of it.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I should at more distance and with more reverence approach you, Madam, did not the shortness of the time, and the great danger of losing you, force me to be free; Throw not away this pretious time, a Minute now is Inestimable.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Yet I must consider on that Minute on which the happiness or Misery of all my Life may depend.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: How can ● imagine that you who have rambled up and down the Southern World, should at last ●ix on a Horne-bred Mistress in the North? how can you be in earnest?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Consult your Understanding and your Looking-Glass, one will tell you how Witty, Wise, and Good you are, the other, how Beautiful, how Sweet, how Charming.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Men before they are Married turn the great end of their Perspective; but the little end after it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They are Men of ill Eyes, and worse Understanding; but for your Perfections there needs no Perspective.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: If I were inclin'd to Marriage, methinks we are not well enough acquainted yet to think of that.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: To my Reputation I suppose you are no Stranger, nor to my Estate, which lies all in the next County; and for my Love, I will convince you of it, by setling what ever you please, or all that Estate upon you before I expect any Favour from you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You are so Generous beyond my Deserts, that I know not how to Credit you.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Your Modesty is too Great, and your Faith too Little.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Death, Who are these whith my Mistress and my Sister? Oh! they are the silly Fellows that we saw at the Spaw, that came hither last night, do you know Sir, that this is my Mistress Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know Sir that no man is worthy of that Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ye● Sir, I will make you know that I am Sir, and She has the Honour to be my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Very well Sir, No 'tis very ill Sir, that you should have the boldness to take my Mistress by the Hand Sir, and if you do Sir, I must tell▪ you Sir— What do you Smile Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A man may do what he will with his own Face. I may Smile Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: If you do Sir, I will fight Sir, I tell you that Sir. hah,

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, you are a Bloody-minded man.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis for my Honour, my Honour, he is plaguely afraid; look you Sir, if you Smile Sir, at me Sir, I will Kick Sir, that's more Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you do, you will be the fifteenth man I have run through the Body Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hah! What does he say, through the Body, oh.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Yonders my Brother, we must not be so perticular, lets joyn.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, the Body Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and my custom is (if it be a great affront, I kill them, for) I rip out their Hearts, dry 'em to Powder, and make Snuff on 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Snuff!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have a box full in my pocket Sir, will you please to take some.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No Sir, I thank you Sir: Snuff quoth a, I will have nothing to do with such a cruel man, I say no more Sir.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir: does he take such Snuff too?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The same— do you hear Sir, if you value your own life, which I will save for the Families sakes, not a word of this to any man.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No Sir, Not I Sir? Your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I ask your pardon Gentlemen, I was stay'd by what, if you please to walk in, will divert you well enough.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Wee will wait on you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Daughter, Sir Ieffery and my Ladys have made complaints of you for abusing Sir Timothy; let me hear no more on't, we have resolv'd the Marriage shall be to Morrow, it will become you to be upon a little better Tearms to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Do you here that Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have sent to Whally for all your Servants, and Horses, and Doggs, you Must do me the honour to Make some stay with me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We cannot enough acknowledg your great Civility.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
No Complements, I obliege my self; Sir
Ieffery Shacklehead
and I have just now agreed, that to morrow shall be the Day of Marriage between our Sons and Daughters.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Very short warning.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Hee I not delay it longer.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I'le in and see what the reason of this sudden resolution.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir we wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Stay you there a while with Sir Timothy.

div.stage: Ex. all but Sir Tim. and Isab.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Dear Cousin, prethee be kinder to me, I protest and vow, as I am a Christian, I love the better then both my Eyes, for all this.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Why how now Dogs face, hast thou the Impudence to make love again,
with that hideous Countenance? that very insipid silly Physnomy of thine? with that most piteous mein? why thou lookst like an Operat●r for Teeth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: This is all sham, I wont beleive it; I can see my self in the great glass, and to my mind no man looks more like a Gentleman than my self.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Gentleman! with that silly wadling shuffling gate? thou hast not mien good enough for a chief Constable, every change of thy Countenance, and every motion of thy Body proclaims thee an Ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, come Madam, I shall please you better when I am Marry'd, with a 〈◊〉 that I have; I tell yee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou makest me sick to see thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I shall be more Familiar with you to Morrow-night, oh my dear rogue— well I say no more, faith I shall, well, no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Be gone thou Basilisk, here, I vow if thou wert the only man on Earth, the Kinde should cease rather than I would Marry thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: You'l be in a better humour to Morrow-night, though you are such a 〈◊〉 now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This place, where some Materials are to mend the Wall, will furnish me with some Ammunition: be gone I say.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I shant do●t, I know when I am in good Company, come prethee Cousin, do not let us Fool any longer, to Morrow we shall be one flesh— de ye see:

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I had rather be inoculated into a Tree, than be made one Flesh with thee; can that Westph●lia hide of thine ever become one Flesh with me? when, I can become one Ass with thee it may, you shall never change my mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, well, I shall have your Body to Morrow-night, and I warrant you your mind shall soon follow it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Be gone, thou infinite Coxcomb, Ile set thee farther.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, what, what a pox! hold, what a Devil, are you mad? Flesh, heart, hold, what a plague, uds bud, I could find in my heart to turn again.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Do filthy Face, do if thou darst.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh help, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I have no patience with this Fool, no Racks, or Tortures shall force me to marry him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I am very indifferent about this Matrimony, and for ought I see, you are so too.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: I must confess you are as fine a Gentlewoman as ever I saw, and I am not worthy of you; but my Father says he will disinherit me, if I will not marry you to Morrow; therefore I desire you would please to think on't.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I will think on't.

sp.speaker: Yo Har.
sp.p:
You shall command all my Estate, and do what you will; for my part, I resolve all my Life, to give up my self wholly to my Sports, and my Horses, and
my Dogs, and to drink now and then a cup of Ale with my Neighbours, I hate Wine.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You will do very well.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: He says we must be Married to Morrow at Ten, I can be going a Hawking by six and come home time enough, I would be loath to neglect my Hawking at Powts in the height of the Season.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: By no means, you'd do very ill if you should.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Ay so I should, but shall I tell my Father that you will have me to Morrow? you know the Writings are Sealed, and Wedding-Cloaths bought of all sides.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Well, I shall do as becomes me.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p:
Well, Cousin there's no more to be said betwixt you and I then,
Pa●ce Verba
, a word to the Wise, I say, is enough, so I rest your humble Servant to command; ●e tell my Father what you say presently, your Servant to, tell you truly I had never so much mind to be Married as now; for I have been so woundedly frightned with Witches, that I am affraid to lye alone, dee see; well, I am glad this business is over: a pox upon all making of Love for me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I thought I saw my Cousin in you Walk, 'tis time for us to consult what to do, my Father and Mother are resolved upon to Morrow for the fatal day.

div.stage:
Enter Smerk, and Priest,
and Mrs.
Susan.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my shoule, Ioy, I thank you for my Fast-break, for it does give refreshment unto me, and Consolaation too gra.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Thank you Mistress Susan, my Caudle was admirable; I am much strengthened by these good Creatures.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Yours was admirable— if Mother Demdike has any Skill, I shall find the opperati●● before night, and I will be reveng'd for his scorn to me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Though thou dosht know me, yet thou dosht shay thou wilt tell nothing concerning of me.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: No, for my part though I differ in some things, yet I honour the Church of Rome as a true Church.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my Shalvaation yee did all come out of us indeed, and I have expectaation daat you will come in agen, and I think I will live to shee it; perhaps I will tell you now, you had your Ordination too with us.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: For my part, I think the Papists are honest, loyal men, and the Iesuits dyed innocent.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat dou dosht not believe de Plot de Devil taak me.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: No, no, no Papist Plot, but a Presbyterian one.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Aboo, boo, boo, By my Shalvaation I will embraash dy Fathers Child, and I will put a great kish upon dy cheeke, now for dat, ay dear ish a damnd Presbyterian Plot to put out de Paapists, and de Priests, and de good Men, and if I would have my minde, de Devil taak me I would shee 'em all broyle and fry in de 〈◊〉 they call Smithfield, 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I wou'd have Surplices cram'd down their Throats, or would have 'em hang'd in 〈…〉.
〈…〉 with these Priests, see they are come from their Breakfast, and 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: 〈…〉 not believe de Paapist Plot my Ioy.
〈…〉 Presbyterian Plot I do: I would be a Turk before I would be a 〈…〉
〈…〉 I vill give Satisf●ction unto dee, and ●aak dee of my Church, we have 〈…〉 of dy Church, and dou art almost as good a Friend as he in de West, I have 〈…〉 take it did begin vid a T.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: How now! Do not you believe a Popish Plot?

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: No, but a 〈◊〉 I do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
This is great Impudence, after the King has affirm'd it in so many Pr●clamations, and three Parliaments have 〈◊〉 it,
Nemine 〈◊〉
.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Parliaments, tell me of Parliaments, with my Bible in my hand, ●le dispute with the whole 〈◊〉 of Commons; Sir, I hate Parliaments, none but Phanaticks, Hobbists, and Athiests, believe the 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my 〈…〉, dou d●sh't maak me weep indeed, by my Shoul, Ioy, dou wilt be a good Catholick, if I will instruct dee, I will weep on dee indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why the true and wise Church of England-men believes it, and are a great Rock against the Church of Rome.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p:
And Preach and Write learnedly against it; but such Fellows as you are scandals to the Church, a
Company of Tantivy Fools
.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
All the Eminent men of the Church of England believe the Plot, and detest it with horror,
and abominate the Religion that contriv'd it.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Not all the Eminent men, for I am of another opinion.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p:
By my shoul, by my Shoud, Ioy, dey are our Enemies, and I would have no fait put upon de●●, but
dis is my dear Friend
.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: This is a Rascal conceal'd in the Church, and is none of it; sure his Patron knows him not.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No certainly!

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: You are Hobbists and Athiests.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: It is noe matter for all daat Ioy, what dey doe shay unto dee for by Chreest, and by Saint Paatrick dey be Heretick Doggs, by my Shalvaation dou dosht maake me weep upon de agen; by de Lady Mary, I think I will be after reconciling deet o de Catholick Church indeed.

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Ieffery, Lady
, Sir Edw. and Isab. and Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell. Doubt.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Is not my Irish man a pleasant fellow?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: A great Father of the Church.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And perhaps may come to be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Sir 〈…〉 to take some informations about Witches, perhaps that may divert you not ill, 'Tis against my opinion, but I give him way.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I hope you are pleas'd to pardon my incivillity, in rushing unawares into your Chamber last night; but I know you are so much a Gentleman, so well-bred▪ and so accomplisht, I know you do—

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: And for that reason I will make you my Confident in a business, that perhaps, I do not know, but I think it may not be t● your disadvantage, I will communicate it to you in private. N●w, Sir Ieffery and I are to take some Examinations. I assist him very 〈…〉 business, or he could never do it.

div.stage: He sits down and La Sha..

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Call in these Fellows, 〈◊〉 hear what they'l say about these Witches; come on, Did you serve my Warrant on Mother Demdike?

div.stage: They call the Constable in and a Country fellow.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, I went to her House (and please your Worship) and lookt in at her Window, and she was feeding three great Toads, and they daunc'd and leapt about her, and she suckled a great black Cat well nigh as big as a Spaniel; I went into the House, and she vanisht, and there was nothing but the Cat in the middle, who spit and star'd at me, and I was frighted away.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: An arch Witch I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I went out at the back-dore, and by the Threshold sat a great Hare, I struck at it, and it run away, and ever since I have had a great pain in my back, and cannot make Water, saving your presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: A fit of the Gravel.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: No, by my shoule, she is a great Witch, and I vil cure you upon ●aat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: No: I tell you, Sir Edward, I am sure she is a Witch, and between you and I, last night, when I would have been kind to my Wife, she bewitcht me, I found it so.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Those things will happen about ●ive and fifty.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
I will tell you now, Joy, I will cure you too.
*
* This Receipt is in Scott. he ha● collected out of Inquisitors and Witch-mongers.
Taak one of de Tooths of a dead man, and bee, and burn it, and taak dee smoke into both your Noses, as you taak Snush, and anoint your self vid dee Gaal of a Crow, taak Quicksilver, as dey do call it, and put upon a Quill, and plaash it under de shoft Pillow you do shit upon, den maake shome waater through de Ring of a Wedding, by St. Patrick, and I will shay shome
Ave Maaries
for dee, and dou wilt be ●ound agen: gra.

sp.speaker: Sir. Ieff.
sp.p: Who is this pretends to skill in Witchcraft?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: A very lea●●ed man in these matters, that comes hither on purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: I shall be glad of your better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I vil be very vel pleash'd to b after being acquainted vid dee Joy.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Have you any more to say? Fellow speak to me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, an't please your Worship forsooth, Mother Demdike said she would be reveng●d on me for not giving her some Butturmilk; and the next night coming from Rachdale, I saw a great Black Hog, and my Horse threw me, and I lost a Hog that night, he dy'd, that was as well when he went to bed, as ever he was since he was born.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, a plain, a manifest Witch, make a Warrant for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Ay, do.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Take some of the Thatch of her House, and burn it at your House, and you shall see she will come streight.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Or to morrow about dawn, piss in a Pot, and cover it with your right, neither Stocking, and the Witch will be tormented in her Bladder, and come to you roaring before night.

div.stage: These two Remedies are in Scott.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: A most profound Science.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And poor old Ignorant wretches must be hang'd for this.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
A Cow of mine is bewitcht too, and runs about the Close as if she were mad; and that, I believe, Mother Hargrave bewitcht, because I deny'd her some
〈◊〉.— good
.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 into the Warrant too: 'Tis enough, a little thing will serve for evidence against ● Witch.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: A very little one.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
*
* This is likewise to be found in Scott. Abundance of this kind is to be seen in
Flagellum Diabol
. in the second Tom. of
Mall. Maleficarum
.
Put a pair of Breeches or Irish Trowsers upon your Cows head, Fellow, upon a Fryday Morning, and wid a great Stick maak beat upon her, till she do depart out of de Close, and she vill repair unto de Witches dore, and she vill knock upon it vid her Horns indeed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Thank you good Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Sir, I see you are a Learned man in this business, and I honour you.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I will put shome holy waater into your Cows mout, and I vill maak Cure upon her for all daat indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Come, has any one else any thing to inform?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Yes an●t please your Worship, here is a Neighbour,
Thomas o Georges
.

sp.speaker: Tho. o G.
sp.p:
Why, an't please your Worships, I was at
Mal. Spencers●
House where he wons 〈◊〉 Lone, and whoo had a meeghty great Cat, a black one by'r Lady, and whoo kist and who clipt Cat, and ay set me down a bit (meet a bit) and believe Cat went under her Coats, Quo ay what don yeo doo with that fow Cat? why, says Whoo, who soukes me. Soukes tee! Marry that's whaint quo ay, by'r Lady what ●an Cat do besides? Why, says whoo, whoost carry me to Rachdale believe. Whaw, quo ay, that's pretty! Why, sayes whoo, ye●st ha one an yeow win to carry yeow; by'r lady, quo ay, with aw my heart, and thank ow too, marry 'twill save my Tit a pow'r of labour; so whoo cawd a Cat to me, a huge Cat, and we ridden both to Rachdale strieght along.

sp.speaker: B●●l.
sp.p: Well said, this was home; I love a Fellow that will go through stitch.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: This is a Witch, indeed, put her name in.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
This is n●w thing by my Shoule, I will tell you now it is naw thing for all daat, a Vich, if she be a good Vitch, will ride upon a Graashopper, I tell you, very well,
and yet a Graashopper is but a weak beast neither; you do maak wonder upon dish but by my Shoule it is naw thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Where did you take Cat, say you, together?

sp.speaker: Tho. o. Geor.
sp.p: Why, we took Cat●ith● Lone meet a mile off.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: So you rid eight mile upon Cats: are there any more informations?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No more an●t please your Worship, but when I have once taken 'em, enough will come in.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Go then about taking 'em, and bring 'em before Sir Ieffery, and my self, Ile warrant you wee'l order 'em.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I will tell you now Fellow, taak de shoe of a Horse, and nayle it upon your Threshold, de plaash dou dosht goe into dy dore upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: And put a Clove of Garlick into the Roof of thy House.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Femel is very good in your House against Spirits and Witches, and Alicium, and the Herb Mullein, and Long-wort, and Moly too is very good.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
*
* This is to be found in Delrio, and Remig. and
Fr. Silvester
.
Burne shome Brimstone, and maak a sweet fume of de Gall of a Black Dogg, Joy, and besmeare dy Pots, and dy Walls, and bee, and Cross dy Self, and I will touch dee vid Reliques, and dee to gra.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Thank you good Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho. o Geor.
sp.p: Thank a.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Is not this an excellent Art?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis so extravagant, that a man would think they were all in Dreams that ever writ of it.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I see no manner of Evidences against these poor Creatures.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I could laugh at these Fools sufficiently, but that all the while our Mistresses are in danger.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Our time is very short, prethee let's consider what is to be done.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, I must open my heart to thee; I am so much in Love with this Bellfort, that I shall dye if I lose him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Poor Isabella, dying is something an inconvenient business; and yet I should live very uncomfortable without my Spark.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Our time's very short, therefore preethee let's play the fool no longer, but come to the point when we meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Agreed: But when shall we meet 'em?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I warrant thee before Midnight.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Come, let us take one turn in the Garden, and by that time my Dinner will be ready.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam, For Heaven's sake consider on what a short time my Happiness or Ruin depends.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir Ieffery and his Lady will be Jealous.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a good sign.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Not a word, we shall be suspected, at night we will design a cenferrence.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: Why so unkind Clod? You frown and wonnot kiss me.
No marry, ●●e be none of thy Imp, I wott.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: What dost thou mean my Love? prethee kiss me.
Stand off by'r Lady an I list kibbo once, 〈◊〉 raddle thy bones: 〈…〉 that, thou art a fow Witch.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Witch● a poor Innocent young Lass, that's whaint, I am not awd 〈◊〉 for that Mon.
And I believe my ●yne, by the Mass I saw you in Sir Yedards Cellar last neeght with your 〈◊〉, thou art a rank Witch, uds flesh I'le not come nere thee.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: Did you see me? Why, if I be a Witch, I am the better Fortune for you, 〈…〉 of the best and be rich.
〈◊〉 marry ●le fare none with thee, Ile not be hang'd, nor go to the Deel 〈…〉 mass, but I will hang thee on I con by'r Lady.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: Say you so Rogue, Ile plague you for that.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: What is whoo gone? ●Tis for no good marry, I ha scap'd a fine waife, a fow 〈◊〉 by'r Lady, I●le hang the Whean and there be no more Witches in Loncashire. 〈◊〉 whats tiss?

div.stage: Mal. Enters with a Bridle, and puts it on ere he is aware.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l:
S.
a
a For these kind of transformations, you will see Authority at the latter end of these Notes.
Horse, Horse, be thou to me,
And carry me where I shall flee.

div.stage: She gets upon him, and flies away.

Enter
Demdike, Dickenson, Hargrave
, &c. with their Imps, and Madg, who is to be the new Witch.

sp.speaker: Demd
sp.l:
b
b For Witches delighting in such solitary places, see Agrippa and Lucan quoted in the second Act.
Within this Shatt●r●d Abby Walls,
This Pit ore grown with Brakes and Briers,
Is fit for our dark Works, and here
Our Master dear, will soon appear,
And make thee Mother Madge a Witch,
〈…〉 be Happy, long-liv'd, Rich,
Thou wi●● be Pow●rful and Wise,
And be reveng'd of thy Enemies.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: 'Tis that I'd have, I thank you Dame,

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l:
c
c Having Imps is to be found in all Authors that treat of Witches. Having of Biggs or Teats, I find no where but in our English Authors, and in late Examinations.
H●r● take this Imp, and let him suck,
H●l do what e're thou bidst him, call
Him 〈…〉,

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.p: Come hither Puck-Hairy.

div.stage: En. an Imp in shape of a black shock, comes to her.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.p: Where is thy Contract written in Blood?

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.p: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: So t'● firm and good.
Where●s my Mamilion● come my Rogue,
And take thy Dinner.

sp.speaker: Dicken.
sp.l: Where●● my Puggy?
Come to me and take thy Duggy.

sp.speaker: Harg.
sp.p:
Come my
Rouney, where art thou?

div.stage:
Enter Mal. Spencer, Leading Clod
in a Bridle
.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Come Sirrah, I have switcht you well
sp.stage: She ties him up, and joyns with the other Witches.
sp.l: I'le tye you up now to the Rack.
Well met Sisters, where●s my Pucklin?
Come away my pretty Sucklin.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Waunds and Flesh, what con Ay do naw, I am turn'd into a Horse, a Capo, a meer Titt; Flesh Ayst ne're be a Mon agen, I marle I con speak, I conno pray, I wot a pox o'th' Deel Mun, Ay live of Oates, and Beans, and Hay aw my life, instead of Beef and Pudding: uds Flesh I neigh too,
Oh who has switcht and spurd me plaguely, I am raw all over me, whoo has ridden a wounded way about too.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: Oyntment for Flying here I have,

d
d
For this Ointment see
Wier. de pr●●●gus Dam. ultimo libro de Lamiis,
he has the Receipt at large,
Puerorum pinguedinem decoquendo ex aqua capiunt inspissando quod ex elixatione ultimum novissimumque subsidet, inde condunt continuoque inserviunt usu●: cum hac immiscent Eleoselinum aconitum frondes popules & fuliginem vel aliter
Of Childrens Fat stoln from the Grave.

e
e sium, acorum vulgare pentaphyllon vespertilion●● sanguinem solanum somniferum, &c.
This Ointment is in
Carda● de su●tiltate, Cap. de Mirabilibus and in Paracelsus de magna & occulta Philosophia, in Delrio Disquis. Mag. Quest. 16. p. 130.
There are under that Question several Stories under Oathes and Confessions, of the Witches night-meetings and flying. See
Bodin
for the Ointment
, lib. 2. Damon. cap. 4. And Scot. p. 182.
The juice of Smallage, and Night-shade,
Of Poplar Leaves, and Aconite made
With these.
The Aromattic Reed I boyl,
With Water-parsnip, and Cinquesoil;
With store of Soot, and add to that,
The reeking Blood of many a Bat.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l:
f
f See the renown'd Iohnson in the last Scene of the second Act of his sad Sheepherd.
From the Seas 〈◊〉 owse a Weed,
I fetch'd to open Locks at need.

g
g ●or. Satyr 8. Vidi equidem nigra succinctam vadere palla Canidiam pedibus nudis passoque Capillo:
and the Verse before
, Ossa legant herbasque nocentes. Ovid. Ep. of Hyps●pile. Per tumulos errat sparsis distincta Capillis. Scnec. de Medea, v. 756. Vinculo solocus Comam secreta nudo nemora lustravi pede. Ovid Metam. 7. Egreditur tectis vestes induta recinctas nuda pedes nudos humoris infusa capillos.
With Coats suckt up, and with my Hair,
All flowing lo●sly in the Air,
With naked Feet I went among

h
h
The use of Herbs in Witchcraft, all Authors both Ancient and Modern take notice of, that treat of Witches.
Virg. Has herbis atque haec 〈◊〉 mihi lecta veneno. Ovid Metam. 7. Protinus horrendis infamia pabula succ●● conterit & tribus Hecateia Carmina miscet. Virg. 3. Georg. Miscueruntque herbas & non innoxia verba: Propert. Quippe & collinas ad fossam moverit herbas. Virg. 4. Aeneid. Falcibus ad Lunae Lumen queruntur 〈◊〉 pubentes herbae nigri cum lacte Veneni,
The poysnous Plants, there Adders
i
i cicuta solanum hyoscyamus Ophiogl●sson, Martagon, Daronicum, Aconitum,
are mention'd by
Paracelsus, Porta and Agrippa,
as especial ingredients in Magick
.
Tongue,
With A●omt● and Martagon,
Henbane, Hemlock, Moon-wort too,

k
k Hor. Ep. 5. In Ca●idian: Iubet sepulchris caprificos er●tas Iubet capressus funebres.
Wild Fig-Tree, that o're Tombs do's grow,
The deadly Night-shade, Cypress, Yew,
And Libbards Bane, and venemous Dew,

I gathered for my Charms. Harg.
l
l Plin. Nat. Hist. lib. 2. cap. 13.
Writing of the Mandrake, says,
Caveant effossuri contrarium ventum & tribus circulis ante gladio circumscribunt postea fodiunt ad occasllm spectantes.
And I
Dug up a Mandrake which did cry,
Three Circles I made, and the Wind was good,
And looking to the West I stood.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.l:
m
m
Hor. Ep. 5. Et uncta turp●● 〈…〉 sanguine plumamque Nocturnae strigis
For the Bones of Frogs, they are used in Love Cups, see Notes in the second Act.
The Bones of Frogs I got, and the Blood,
With Screetch-Owls Eggs, and Feathers too.

n
n For the Owl●-eyes, Bats-blood and wings, see
Corn. Agrippa d● occulta Philosophia. lib. 1. cap. 15. and cap.
25. The Toad is said to be of great use in Magick see
Pliny, Nat. Hist. lib. 32. cap.
5. A Cats Brain is an ingredient in Love-Cups; see the Notes on the second Act.
Here's a Wall-Toad, and Wings of Bats,
o
o
The Contract signed with Blood
, Bodin lib. 2. cap. 4.
and most Authors speaks of; but
Guaccius
in his
Compend. Malefie.
sets it down at large, of which these are heads:
1. Abn●gant fidei & Creatori, &c. 2. Diabolu● illos tingit Lavacro novi baptismatis. 3. Negato nomine novum illis inditur. 4. C●git abnegare patrinis & matrinis, &c. 5. Lamiae diabolo dant frustum aliquod vestimenti. 6. Prestant Demoni juramentum super circulo in terram sculpto. 7. Petunt a Daem●ne de●eri de libro vitae & scribi in libro mortis. 8. Pollicentur sacrificia & quaedam striges promittunt se singulis mensibus vel quindenis unum infantulum strigando, i. e. exsugendo occissur●;
this is to be found also in
Bart. Spine●s, Quest de st●igibus, 2. cap. 9. Quotannis aliquid magistellis vel Daemonibus pendere tenentur.
See also
Remigius, lib. 1. 11. cap. 10. Corporis alicui parti characterem solet imponere: signum non est semper idem forma, aliquando est simile ●eporis vestigio, aliquando b●fonis pedi, aliquando araneae vel catello vel gliri.
Concerning this mark
, see Bodin, lib. 2. cap. 4. Ludwig. Elich. p. 58. quest. 4. Nic. Remigius. lib. 1. c. 5. pag. 58.
I put this down at large, because some were so ignorant to condemn this contract, as if it were my profane invention, and so silly, that they would have the Devil and Witches speak piously.
The Eyes of Owls, and Brains of Cats.

div.stage: The Devil appears in Humane Shape with four Attendants

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: Peace, here's our Master him Salute,
And kiss the Toe of his Cloven Foot,
Now our new Sister we present,
The Contract too, sign it with Blood.

div.stage: Madge signs it with her Blood.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: First, Heaven you must renounce.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Your Baptism, thus I wash out too.
The new Name Maudlin you must take,
And all your Gossips must forsake,
And I these new ones for you make.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: A piece of your Garment now present.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: Here, take it Master, I'm content.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: Within this Circle I make here,
Truth to our Master you must swear.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: You must each month some murdered Children pay,
Besides your yearly tribute at your day.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Some Secret part I with my mark must sign.
A lasting token, that you are wholy mine.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.l: Oh!

div.stage: The Devil takes her hands between his.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: Now do your Homage.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Curse Heaven, Plague Mankind, go forth and be a Witch.

div.stage: The Musick sounds in the Air.

div.head: Song.
div.l: WElcome, welcome, happy be,
In this blest Society.

lg.l: Men and Beasts are in thy Power,
Thou canst Save, and canst Devour,
Thou canst Bless, and Curse the Earth,
And cause Plenty, or a Dearth.

div.l: Welcome, &c.

lg.l: O're Natures Powers thou canst prevail,
Raise Winds, bring Snow, or Rain, or Hail;
Without their Causes, and canst make
The steady Course of Nature shake.

div.l: Welcome, &c.

lg.l: Thou canst mount upon the Clouds,
And skim o're the ruggid Floods;
Thou canst dive to the Sands below,
And through the sollid earth canst go.

div.l: Welcome, &c.

lg.l: Thou'lt open Looks, or through a Chink
Shalt creep for daintiest Meat and Drink.
Thou maist sleep on tops of Trees,
And lye in Flowers like Humble Bees.

div.l: Welcome, &c.

lg.l: Revenge, revenge, the sweetest part
Of all thou hast by thy black Art.
O● Heaven thou ne're shalt f●x thy mind,
For here 'tis Heav'n to plague mankind.

div.stage: They Dance with fantastick unusual postures

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l:
p
p Lucan, lib. 6. Cessavere vices 〈◊〉 dilataque longe haesit nocte dies: legi non paruit Aether. Sen. Med. pariterque mundus, lege confusa Aetheres & solem & astra vidie & vetitum mare tetigistis u●sae●temporum flexi vices.
At your command all Natures course shall cease,
And all the Elements make war or peace:
The Sky no more shall its known Laws obey,
Night shall retreat whilst you prolong the day.

q
q Ovid. Ep. Hypsip. Illa reluctantem cursu diducere lunam nititur & tenebris abdere solis equos metam 7. de Medea & te luna traho. Pet. Arbiter makes a
Witch, boasting her power, among many other things, say,
Lunae descendit imago carminibus deducta men,
the whole discription is very elegant.
Hor. E●od. 5. Quae ●idera excantata voce Thessala Lunamque coelo deripti. Id. Ep. 18. in fine Epodos deripere lunam voci●●●possum meis. Tibul. lib. 〈◊〉. Eleg. 2. Hanc ego de coelo ducentem sydera vidi. Propert. Audax canta●e l●ges impouere Lunae.
Thy Charms shall make the Moon and Stars come down,
And in thick darkness, hide the Sun at Noon.

r
r Ovid. Metam. 7. Nubilaque induco ventos abigoque vocoque.
Winds thou shalt raise, and streight their rage controul.
Hearing thy mighty Charms, the troubled Sky
Shall crack with Thunder, Heav'n not knowing why.

t
t 〈◊〉 ibid. ventis cessantibus aequor in●umuit; rursus vetitum sentire procellas conticuit turbante noto: Sen. Medea. son●ere fluctus tumuit 〈◊〉 mare tacente vento. Id. Herc. Oct. concussi fretum cessante vento turbidum explicu● mare.
Without one puff the Waves shall foam and rage,
Then though all Winds together should ingage,
The silent Sea shall not the Tempest feel.

u
u Virg. Aeneid. lib. 4. mugire videbis sub pedibus terram & descendere ●iontibus orn●s. Metam. 7. Iubeoque tremescere montes & mugire solum. Lucan lib. 6. has a bolder expression,
Terra quoque immoti concussit ponderis axem, & medium vergens nisu titubavit in orbem.
Vallies shall roar, and trembling Mountains reel.

x
x Metam. 7. Vivaque saxa sua convulsaque robora terra & 〈…〉 Ovid. Ep. Hypsip. Illa loco sylvas vivaque saxa movet. Sen. H●rc. Oct. habnere motum saxa.
At thy command Woods from their seats shall rove,
Stones from their Quarries, and fixt Oaks remove.

y
y Metam. 7. Cum vol●● ripis i●sis mirantibus amnes in fontes rediere suos, conc●ssaque fistto stantia concu●io, Virg. Aeneid. 4. Sistere aqu●n 〈◊〉 & flimina vertere retro▪ Tibull,
following the Verse beforecited
, Fluminis h●c rapids carmins vertit iter, Sen▪ Med. violenta phanis vertit in fo●tem vada, & Ister in tot or a divisus truces compeseit 〈◊〉 omnibus rip●● piger.
Vast standing lakes shall flow, and, at thy will,
The most impetuous Torrents shall stand still:
Swift Rivers shall (while wond'ring Banks admire)
Back to their Springs, with violent hast, retire.

z
z Ovid. Amor. 3. Eleg. 6. Carmine laera Ceres sterilom 〈◊〉 in herba●● Virg. Eclog. 8.
Speaking of
Maeris Atque satas alio vidi traducere messes.
Thy Charms shall blast full Fruits, and ripen'd Ears.

a
a Aeneid. 4. Haec se carminibus promittit solvere ments quas velit, ast aliis d●●ras immittere curas.
Ease anxious minds, and th●n afflict with cares.

b
b 〈◊〉 lib. 6. Carmine T●e●salidum dura in praecordia fluxit non fati● adductus amor.
Give Love, where Nature cannot, by thy skill,
And any living creature save or kill:

c
c Hor. Epod. 18. Possum ●rematos excit●● mortuos desiderique temperare poculum.
The raising of Ghosts, and transforming themselves and others, all Witchmongers both ancient and modern affirm.
Virg. Aeneid.
the place before quoted
, Necturn●●que ci●t m●nes. Id Eclog. 8. Has herbas atque haec Ponto mihi lecta v●naena ipsa dedit. Maeris nascuntur, pluri●n● Ponto, His ego saepe lupam fieri & se condere sylvis Maerim saepe animas exire sepulchris vidi, &c. Propertius
before cited
, Audax, &c. & sua nocturno 〈◊〉 terga lupo.
You may see
Lucan makes Erictho
raise a Ghost
, Seneca's untrix in He●c. O●teus: And T●resias in Oedipus
do the same, all Witchmongers are full of it. In
Bodin Daemon. lib. 2. cap. 6.
There is a great deal of stuff about Transformations; he says, Witches transform themselves into Wolves, and others into Asses; and I think those are they that believe im 'em: He is very angry with Physicians that
call ●ycanthropia
disease; he says, divers Witches at
Vernon
turn'd themselves into Cats, and tells a story of three Witches at
A●gentine
that turn'd themselves into Cats, and beat and wounded a Faggot-maker. This also
Petr. de Lover de spectris
mentions in English Translation, p. 128. He says there, that in his time a Hermit of
Dore
was turn'd into a Wolf and was going to devour a little Child, if he had not been surprif●d and discovered; and a Merchant of
Cyprus
was turn'd into as Ass; indeed, he says, the Devil does not change the body, but only abuse and delude the fancy; and quotes
Thomas Aquinas in 2 〈◊〉. distinct. 8. Aug. lib 18. de Civit. Dei,
says, he himself knew the Father of one
〈◊〉
who was changed into Mule, and did carry upon hi●● back Bag and Baggage for Soldiers; but he says this was an illusion of the Devil, and that the Father of
〈◊〉
was not really changed into a Mule, but the eyes of the beholders were enchanted.
Bodin
〈…〉 in the shape of a Wolf, kill'd a Child of Twelve years old, eat up her Arms and Legs, 〈…〉 And
Peter Burgis, and Michael Werdon,
having turn'd 〈…〉 of people: Such impossible Stories does this
helluo
〈…〉 him, swallow himself, and disgorge to us. He says, the matter of Transformations 〈…〉 Seventh, and by him were all judged possible.
Wierus ultimo libro 〈…〉 quoque refertur quod se in Lupos 〈…〉
I should have mentioned the transformations of
Lucian and Apuleius, which Bodin 〈…〉
the Seventh made Canonical: I could cite many more Authorities for this, and for most of 〈…〉 in the fore-written Speech; but I shall ●ire the Reader and my self: I have not endeavoured 〈…〉 the Poets so much as to take thoughts from them. For the manner of their Musick, see
〈…〉 quest. 10. p. 13. and Remigius Daemonolat, lib. 1. cap. 19. Miris modis illic 〈…〉 &c. strepant sous inconditis absurdis ac discrepantibus canit hic Daemon 〈…〉 aliquod quod forte humi repertum buccam seu tibiam 〈…〉 lib. 2. cap. 4.
who says they Daunce with Brooms. And
Remigius, lib. 1. 〈…〉 18. Omnia fiunt ritu 〈◊〉 & ab omni hominum consuetudine alienum, dorsis invicem 〈…〉
Raise Ghosts, transform your self and whom you will.

div.stage:
Enter
Tom. Shacklehead
, with a Gun on his shoulder.

sp.speaker: Demd.
sp.l: Who's here? who's here?

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.l: Waunds what●s here? The Witches By'r Lady,
I'le shoot amongst 'em: have at ye.
sp.stage:
They all vanish, and
Clod Neigh●
sp.l: Hey, Dive-dappers, Dive-dappers:
What a Devils here! Clod tied by a Bridle and Neighing! What a Pox ail'st thou?
Const a tell?

div.stage:
Tom. Shac.
takes off the Bridle.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Uds flesh, I am a Mon agen naw!
Why, I was a Horse, a meer Tit, I had lost aw
My speech, and coul'd do naught but neigh;
Flesh I am a Mon agen.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.l: What a dickens is the fellee wood?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Ise ta the Bridle with me, fly from the Dee'l, and the Witches, and I'le tell you
aw at the Ale-house.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.l: What a murrain ails the Hobbell?
I mun follow, and see what's the matter.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Sir Edward, Sir Ieffery, La. Shaklehead, Sir Timothy and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sir Ie●●.
sp.p: I Am sorry I am forced to complain of my Cosin.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Sorry, marry so am not I; I am sorry she is so pert and ill-bred, truly Sir Edward 'tis unsufferable for my Son, a man of his Quality and Title, Born of such a Family, and so Educated, to be so abused, to have Stones thrown at him li●e a Dog.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: We must e'en break off the Match, Sir Edward.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Sir, I am ashamed of it, I blush and grieve to hear it; Daughter, I never thought to see this day.
Sir, I am so amazed I know not what to say, I abuse my Cosin! Sure he is bewitched.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I think I am, to Love you after it, I am sure my Arm's black and blew, that it is.
He ●ested with me, as I thought, and would have ruffled me, and kissed me, a●d I run from him, and in foolish play, I quoited a little Stone or two at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And why did you call me Filthy-face, and ugly Fellow, h●h, Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: La. Sha
sp.p: He ugly! Nay, then I have no Eyes, though I say't, that should not say't, 〈…〉 his Fellow—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nor I neither: 'twas a jest, a jest, he told me he was handsomer for a Man, than I for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Why, look you there, you Blockhead, you Clown, you Puppy, why do you trouble us with this impertinent lye?

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Good words, Sir Ieffery, 'twas not so much amiss; hah, I'le tell you that.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Sure this is some mistake, you told me you were willing to marry.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I did not think I should be put to acknowledg it before this Company: But Heaven knows, I am not more willing to live; the time is now so short, I may confess it.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: You would not use him, you intend to marry, ill.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I Love him I am to marry more than Light or Liberty. I have thus long dissembled it through Modesty; but, now I am provoked, I beseech you Sir, think not that I'd dishonour you so.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Look you, you have made her weep; I never found her false or disobedient.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, good dear Cousin, don't cry, you'l make me cry too; I can't forbear, I ask your pardon with all my heart, I vow I do, I was to blame, I must confess.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Go too, Sir Timothy, I never could believe one of your parts would play the Fool so.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: And you will marry to morrow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I never wisht for any thing so much, you make me blush to say this.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Sweet Cousin forgive me, and Sir Ieffery, and Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Can I be angry at any thing▪ when I am to be married to morrow? And I am sure I will be, to him I love more than I hate this Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to break your head, Sir Timothy, you are a Puppy.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Come lets leave 'em together, to understand one another better.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Cousin, Daughter I should say, I beg your pardon, your Servant.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Servant, Sweet Daughter.

div.stage:
Ex. Sir
Edw. Sir Jeff.
and Lady
.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Dear Cosin be in good humour, I could wish my self well beaten for mistaking one that loves me so, I would I might ne're stir, if I did not think you had been in earnest: well, but I vow and swear I am mightily beholden to you, that you think me so fine a person, and love me so dearly; Oh how happy am I that I shall have thee to morrow in these Arms! by these ten bones, I love you more than all the Ladies in London put them together. Prethee Speak to me, O that Smile Kills me, oh I will so Hug thee and Kiss thee, and Love thee to morrow night— I'd give forty pound to morrow night were to night, I hope we shall have twins before the year comes about▪

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Do you so Puppy?

div.stage: She gives him a box on the Ear, and pulls him by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Help, Help, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Help, Help, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a Devils to do now? hah, she Counterfeits a Sound.

div.stage: Enter Theodosia at one Door, and Sir Ieffery, and Lady a● the other.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: How now, my Dear, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I feel the matter, She gave me a Cuff, and lug'd me by the Ears, and I think she is in a Sound.

sp.speaker: I●ab.
sp.p: Oh the Witch! the Witch came just now into the Room, and struck Sir Timothy, and Lug'd him, and beat me down.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Lord, a Witch! Ay, 'twas a two legg'd Witch.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And, assoon as she had done, she run out of that Door.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, I met her and was frighted, and left her muttering in the next 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Impudence!

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: You Puppy, you Coxcomb, will you never leave these lyes, is the fellow bewitched?

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Go Fool, I am ashamed of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Let●s see if we can take this Witch.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Quickly, before she flies away.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, I have done, I'le ne're tell tale more.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Begone, Fool, go.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, I will endure this, but I am resolved to marry her to morrow and be revenged on her; if she serves me so then, I will tickle her Toby for her, faith I will.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well, I'le be gone, and get out of the way of 'em.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Yo. Harf.
sp.p: Madam! Cozen hold a little, I desire a word with you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I must stay.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Adieu then.

sp.speaker: Yo. Harf.
sp.p: I am drunken well 〈◊〉, and now I am not so hala (since we must marry to morrow) I pray you now let us be a little better acquainted to neeght, He make bold to Salute you in a Civil way.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: The Fool's drunk.

sp.speaker: Yo. Harf.
sp.p: By the Mass she kisses rarely, uds lud she has a Breath as sweet as a Cow, I have been a Hawking, and have brought you home a power of Powts in my bag here; we have had the rarest sport, we had been at it still, but that 'tis neeght.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You have been at some other sport I see.

sp.speaker: Yo. Harf.
sp.p: What, because I am merry? nay, and I list, I can be as merry as the best on 'em all.
sp.l: An onny mon Smait my Sweet hear●,
Ayst Smait him agen an I con,
Flesh what care for a brokken Yead,
For onest a mon's a mon.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I see you can be merry indeed.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Ay that I can, Fa, la, la, fa, la.
I was at it helter Skelter in excellent Ale, with Londoners that went a Hawking, brave Roysters, honest fellows that did not beleive the Plot.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Why don't you beleive the Plot?

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: No, the Chaplain has told me all; there's no Popish Plot, but there's a Presbyterian one, he says, none but Phanaticks believe it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: An Excellent Chaplain to make love to his Patrons Daughter, and Corrupt the Son.
Why all the Eminent men of our Church beleive it; this fellow is none of the Church, but crept into it for a livelyhood, and as soon as they find him they'l turn him out of it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Nay, Cousin I should not have told it, he Charged me to say nothing of it; but you and I are all one, you are to be bone of my bone to morrow: And I will Salute you once more upon that d'e see.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Hold, Hold, not so fast 'tis not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: 'Twill come to that and more to morrow, fa, la, la, but I'le out at four a Hawking, though for all that, d'e understand me?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Her'e's Doubty, I must get rid of this fool.
Cousin, I hear your Father coming; if he sees you in this Condition hee'l be very Angry.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Thank you Kindly, no more to be said, I'le go and Sleep a little, I see she loves me, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Doubty.
sp.p: Dear Madam, this is a happy 〈◊〉 thrown upon me unexpectedly, and I must use it: To morrow is the faral day to ruin me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: It shall not ruin me: the Inquisition should not force me to a Marriage with this fool.

sp.speaker: Doubty.
sp.p: This is a step to my Comfort; but when your Father shall to morrow hear your refusal, you know not what his passion may produce; restraint of Liberty is the least.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: He shall not restrain my Liberty of Choice.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Put your self into those hands that may defend you from his Power: the hands of him, who loves you more than the most Pious value Heaven, than Misers Gold, than Clergy men love Power, than Lawyers strife, than Jesuites Blood and Treachery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: If I could find such a man.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Then look no farther Madam, I am he; speak but one word, and make me the happiest man on Earth.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: It comes a little to quick upon me; are you sure you are the man you speak of?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: By Heaven; and by your Self I am, or may I be the scorn of all Mankind; and the most Miserable too, without you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Then you shall be the man.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Heaven; on my Knees I must receive this Blessing; there's not another I would ask, my Joy's too big for me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: No Raptures for Heavens sake, here comes my Mother, adieu.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I must Compose my self.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Sir your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Your Ladiships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: It is not fit I should lose this opportunity, to tell you that (which perhaps may not be unacceptable to a person of your Complexion) who is so much a Gentleman, that I'le swear I have not seen your equal.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Dear Madam, you confound me with your Praises.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I vow 'tis true; indeed I have strugled with my self before I thought fit to reveal this: but the consideration of your great accomplishments, do indeed, as it were, ravish, or extort it from me, as I may so say.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I beseech you Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: There is a Friend of mine, a Lady (whom the world has acknowledged to be well bread, and of Parts too, that I must say, and almost confess) not in the Bud indeed, but in the Flower of her Age, whom time has not yet invaded with his injuries; in fine, envy cannot say that she is less than a full ripe Beauty.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: That this Creature should bring forth such a Daughter.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Fair of Complexion, Tall, Streight, and shaped much above the ordinary; in short, this Lady (whom many have Languished, and Sigh'd in vain for) does of her self, so much admire your Person, and your Parts, that she extreamly desires to contract a Friendship with you, intire to all intents and purposes.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible she should be in earnest, Madam, but were she, I cannot Marry ever.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Why she is Married already, Lord how dull he is! she is the best Friend I have, Married to an old man, far above her sprightly years.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: What a Mother-in-Law am I like to have!

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Can you not Guess who this is all this while?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.l: Too well.
Not I truly Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, no! that's strange, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I cannot possibly.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. I'le swear! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: No, I●le swear.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: 'Tis very much, you are an ill guesser, I'le vow, ha, ha, ha! Oh Lord, not yet?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Not yet, nor ever can.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Here's Company, retire.

div.stage: Enter Smerk and Tegue O Divelly.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I am all on fire, what is it that Inspires me! I thought her ugly once, but this morning thought 〈…〉 in love already! Sure I was blind, she is a beauty 〈…〉 a minutes absence is death to me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat Joy, dou art in Meditaation and Consideraation upon something? if it be a Scruple upon thy Conscience, I believe I vill maak it out unto dee.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p:
No Sir, I am only ruminating a while; I am inflamed with her affection, O
Susan! Susan
! Ah me! Ah me!

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat dost dou not mind me? nor put dy thought upon me? I do desire to know of dy Faathers Child, what he does differ from de Caatholick Church in, by my fait it is a braave Church, and a gaallant Church (de Devil taake mee) I vill tell you now, phare is dere such a one? vill you speak unto me now Joy, hoh?

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine Church, a Church of Splender, and riches, and power, but there are some things in it—

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Shome things! Phaat dosht dou taalk of shome things? By my shoule I vill not see a better Church in a Shommers day, indeed, dan de Caatholick Church. I tell you there is braave dignities, and promotions too; what vill I shay unto you? by St. Phaatrick, but I do beleeve I vill be a Cardinal before I vill have death. Dey have had not one Eerish Cardinal a great while indeed.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: What power is this that urges me so fast, oh Love! Love!

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat dosht dou shay, dosht dou love promotions and dignities? den I predee now be a Caatholick. What vill I say unto you more? but I vill tell you, You do shay dat de Caatholicks may be shaved, and de Caatholicks do shay, dat you vill be after being damn'd, and phare is de solidity now of daat, daat dou vill not turn a good Caatholick?

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I cannot beleive there is a Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: No! Phy I vill tell you what I vill shay unto you, I have sheen many Shoules of Purgatory dat did appear unto me; And by my trot, I do know a Shoule when I do shee it, and de Shoules did speak unto me, and did deshire of me dat I vould pray dem out of that plaashe: And dere Paarents, and Friends did give me shome money, and I did pray 'em out. Widout money indeed, we cannot pray dem out, no fait.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: That may not be so hard; but for Transubstantiation, I can never beleive it.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Phaat dosht not beleive de Cooncel of Trent Joy? dou vilt be damn'd indeed, and de Devil take me, if dou dosht not beleive it. I vill tell you phaat vill I say to you, a Cooncel is infalible; and I tell you, de Cardinals are infalible too, upon occaasion, and dey are damn'd Heretick Dogs, by my shoulvaation, dat do not beleive every oord dey vill speak indeed.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I feel a flame within me, oh Love, Love, wether wilt thou carry me?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Art thou in love Joy? by my shoule dou dosht Comitt fornicaation, I vill tell you it is a veniall Sinn, and I vill after be absolveing you for it: but if dou dosh Comitt Marrage, it is mortall, and dou vilt be damn'd and bee fait and trot. I predee now vill dou fornicate and not Marry: for my shaake now vilt dou fornicate.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Sure I am bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Bewitch'd in love, Aboo! boo! I'le tell you now, you must taake de Womans
*
* Vide Scot. Discovery &c.
Shoe dat dou dosht Love sho, and dou must maak a Jaakes of it, dat is to shay, dou must lay a Sirreverence, and be in it, and it will maake cure upon dee.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p:
Oh the Witch! the Witch!
Mal. Spencer
, I am struck in my Bowels, take
her away, there, oh! I have a Thousand Needles in me, take her away, Mal. Spencer.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Phaare is shee
, Mal. Spencer. Exercize te Conjure te in Nomine, &c.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh, I have a Million of Needles Pricking my Bowels.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I vill, set up a hubub for dee, help! help! who is dere? help, Aboo, boo, boo.

div.stage: Enter Sir, Ieffery, and Lady, and Susan.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p:
Oh Needles! Needles! Take away
Mal. Spencer
, take her away.

sp.speaker: Sir, Ieff.
sp.p: He is bewitch'd, some Witch has gotten his Image, and is tormenting it.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Hold him, and I vill taak some course vid him, he is possess'd, or obess'd, I vill touch him vid some Relicks.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, good Sir, help him, what shall I do for him?

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Get some Lead melted (and holding over his body) power it into a Poringer full of Water, and if there appear any image upon the Lead, then he is bewitch'd.

div.stage:
This experiment is to be found in
Mal. Mallific
.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Peash, I shay, here is shome of St. Phaatricks own Whisker, and some of the Snuff he did use to taak, dat did hang upon his Beard; here is a Tooth of St. Winifred, indeed, here is a Corn from de Toe of St. Ignatius, and here is de paring of his Nails too.

div.stage: He rubs him with these Relicks.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh worse, worse, take her away.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my shoule it is a very strong Devil, I vill try some more, here is St. Caaterine de Virgins Wedding-Ring, here is one of St. Bridge●s Nipples of her Tuggs, by my shoule, here is some of de sweat of St. Francis, and here is a piece of St. Laurence's Gridiron, dese vill make Cure upon any shickness, if it be not ones lasht shickness.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: What will become of me, I have poyson'd him, I shall lose my Lover, and be hang'd into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh! I dye, I dye, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my shoule it is a very strong Devil, a very aable Devil, I vill run and fetch shome Holy-vater.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Look up, dear Sir, speak to me, ah woes me, Mr. Smerk, Mr. Smerk.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: This Irish-man is a Gallant man about Witches, he out does me.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: But I do not know what to think of his Popish way, his Words, his Charms, and Holy Water, and Relicks, methinks he is guilty of Witchcrast too, and you should send him to Goal for it.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

div.stage: Enter Priest with a Bottle of Holy-water.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Now, I varrant you Joy, I vill do de Devil's business for him, now I have dis Holy-Vater.
The Bottle flies out of his hand.
Phaat is de matter now? phare is dis Devil dat does taak my Holy-Vater from me? He is afraid of it; I shee my bottle, but I do not shee de Devil does taake it. I vill Catch it from him.

div.stage: The Bottle, as he reaches at it, flyes from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: This is wonderful!

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Most amazing!

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Conjure te malum 〈◊〉, Conjure te pessir●● in 〈◊〉, redde mihi me●● (〈◊〉 Latime)
Bottle, phaat vill I do? It is gone

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: 'Tis strange: You se he does not fear holy-water.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I tell you phaat is de matter, by my Shoule he vill touch de Bottle, because daat is not Consecrate; but, by my fait, he will not meddle vid de Vater. I vill ferch shome, I have in a Baashon.

div.stage: He runs out and fetches a Bason of Water.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: He lyes as if he were a Sleep.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh! I begin to have some ease.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I did never meet vid a Devil dat did Cosht so much Laabour before.
sp.stage: He throws Water in Smerks Fact.
sp.p:
Exercis● te Demonens fuge, fuge, Exerciso te, per Melchefideck, per
Bethlehem Gabor
, per omne quod Exit in um seu Graecum sive Latinum.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I am much better now, and the Witch is gone.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Good Sir retire to your Chamber, I will fetch some Cordials.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Sweet beautiful Creature! How I am Enamour'd with thee! Thy beauty dazles like the Sun in his Meridian.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Beauty, Enamourd! Why he seems distracted still; lead him to his Chamber, and let him rest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Now Joy, dosht dou shee, I have maade a Miracle by my shoule. Phen vill I shee one of your Church maake a Miracle, hoh? by my Shoulevaation dey cannot maake Miracles out of de Caatolick Church, I tell you now, hoh.
sp.stage: Mother Demdike enters invisible to them and boxes the Priest.
sp.p:
Phaat is de matter now, ah? by my shoule shomething does cuff upon my faash, an bee,
Exercise te in ●omine, nomine,
by my shoule Saatan, I vill pelt dee vid Holy-Vater indeed; he is Angry dat I did make a Miracle.

div.stage: Mother Demdike gets behind him, and Kicks and Beats him.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: What is this, I hear the blows, and see nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: So do I, I am frighted and amazed; lets fly.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Oh, oh, vat is dis for Joy, oh, all my Holy-Vater is gone, I must fly.

div.stage: He mutters and Crosses himself, and the Wuch beats him out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All this day have I watched for this opertunity, let me improve it now. Consider, Madam, my Extream Love to you, and your own harred to that Fool, for whom you are designed to morrow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: My consent is to be had first.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Fathers resentment of your refusal, may put you out of all possibillity of making me happy, or providing for your own Content.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: To Marry one against his Consent is a Crime heel ne're forgive.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Though his Engagement to Sir Ieffery would make him Refuse his Consent beforehand: He is too reasonable a man to be troubled afterwards, at your Marrying to a better Estate, and to one that loves more than he can tell you: I have not words for it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Though I must Confess you may deserve much better, would you not Imagine I were very forward to receive you upon so short an Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Would I had a Casement in my Breast. Make me not, by your delay, the miserablest wretch on Earth. (Which I shall ever be without you) think quickly Madam, you have not time to Consider long, I lay my self at your Feet, to be for ever made happy or miserable by you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: How shall I be sure you'l not deceive me? These hasty vows, like Angry words, Seldom shoes the Heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By all the Powers of Heaven and Earth.

sp.speaker: Isab.
