sp.p: Hold, Swear not, I had better take a man of honour at his Word.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And may Heaven throw its Curses on me when I break it; my Chaplin's in the House, and passes for my valet de Chambre. Will you for ever make me Happy Madam?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Ile trust your honour; and I'le make my self so; I throw my self upon you, use me nobly: now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Use yee, as I would use my Soul; my Honour, my Heart, my Life, my Liberty, and all I have is yours. There's not a man in all the World, that I can envy now, or wish to be.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Take care, we shall be spyed: The short time I have to resolve in, will, I hope, make you have a better Opinion of my modesty, than otherwise you would have occasion for.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dearest! Sweetest of Creatures! my Joy distracts me, I cannot speak to you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: For Heavens sake leave me, if you raise a Jealously in the House I am ruin'd, we'll meet soon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Adieu my Life! my Soul! I am all obedience.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh my Dear, I am happy, all's out that pained me so; my Lover knows I love him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I have Confessed to my Ghostly Father too, and my Conscience is at ease.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Mine received the news with more Joy, than he Could put in Words.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ieffery, Lady, and Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: And mine in rapture; I am the happiest Woman Living.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I'le not yeild to you at all in that.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: There's no cause, I would not submit to you in, but this my Dear.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I will hold out in this cause while I have breath, I am happier in my Choyce than all the World can make me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Mine is the Hansomest, Wittiest, most accomplisht Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Mine is the beautifullest, sweetest, well-shap'd, well-bred, wittiest Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That must be I, whom she means, for all my Quarrels with her.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Peace, we shall hear more.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Little think our Fathers how happy we shall be to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: What's that? Listen.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: (If no unlucky Accident should hinder us) we shall be farr happier than they can Imagine.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: How we have Cheated them all this while!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: 'Slife they are behind us, stirr not. We have hidden our love from them all this while.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Have you so? but we shall find it now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Your Brother Little thinks I Love him so; For I have been Cross and coy to him on purpose. I shall be the happiest Woman in him, I am to have, that ever was.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I could wish your Brother lov'd me as well as mine does you. For never Woman loved the man she was to Marry as I do him, I am to have to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: That's my best Daughter, thou wert ever a good Child, nay blush not, all is out, we heard ye both.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, all is out, my pretty Dear dissembler: well, I protest and vow, I am mightily obliged to you for your great love to me, and good opinion of me.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.l: I hope to morrow will be a happy day for both our families.
sp.stage:
Enter Sir
Edward, Bellfort and Doubty,
and Musicians
.
sp.p: Oh Sir Edward, is not that strange I told you, I should not have beleived it if I had not seen it.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: And pray give me the same liberty: But now wee'l have some musick, that's good against inchantment, Sing me the Song I Commanded you, and then wee'l have a dance before we go to bed.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Hoh, 'tis a pretty Shong, but I vill shing a brave Cronan now, dat is better I tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
'Tis very fine but sing me one Song more in three parts, to sweeten our Ears, for all that.
*
* They gave and streyn, but cannot sing, but make an ugly noise.
Why what's the matter? you gape and make faces, and do not sing, what's the matter, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Doe you play, play I say, Oh they are bewitch'd, I vill shay no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Play I say.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: I can't, my Arms are on the sudden stiff as marble, I cannot move them.

div.stage: They hold up their bows, but cannot play. Exit. Priest.

sp.speaker: Sir. Edw.
sp.p: Sure this is roguery, and Confederacy.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Conjuro te conjuro in nonime, &c.

div.stage: The Priest. come in with Holy-Water and slings it upon them So long till they run out roaring▪

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Hold, hold, prethee don't duck us all we are not all bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I tell you it ish good for you an bee, and vill defend you upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Now you see, Sir, with your own Eyes; cannot you give us a Receipt to make Holy-water?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
A Resheit, aboo, boo, boo; by my Shoule he is a Foole. I have ma●●e
two Hogsheads gra: and I vill have you vash all de Rooms vid it, and de Devill vill not come upon de plaash by my Shalvaation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis a little odd; but however, I shall not fly from my Belief, that every thing is done by Natural Causes, because I cannot presently assign those Causes.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: You are in the right, we know not the powers of matter.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: When any thing unwonted happens, and we not see the cause, we call it unnatural and miraculous.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my Shoule you do talke like Heretick-Dogs, and Aathiests.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Let us enquire farther about these Musicians.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
I vill maake shome Miracles, and I think I vill be after reconcileing dem indeed, oh dou damn'd vitch.
Ex. all but Priest.
Now I doe shee dee I vill beat upon dee vid my Beads
Mother Dick▪ rises up, and boxes him, be strikes her with Beads, and see him with her Staff, and beats him out.
and Crucifix, oh, oh, shee is a damn'd Protestant Heretick Vitch, daat is de reason she vill not fly, oh, oh, oh.

div.stage:
Enter Tom Shaklehead, and Clod,
in the Field
.

sp.speaker: Tho. Sha.
sp.p: Byr Lady 'tis meeghty strong Ale, Ay am well neegh drunken, and my Nephew will bee stark wood, his Hawkes want their Pidgeon saw this neeght.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why what wouden yeow bee a Angee? Flesh, Ay ha getten de Bridle byr Lady, Ayst ma some body carry mee, and bee my Titt too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thou'rt a strange Fillee (Horse I should say) why didst thou think thou wast a Titt when th' Bridle was on thee.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay marry, I know weel I am sure, I wott I was a Titt, a meere Titt.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Listen, there's a noise of women in the Ayr, it comes towards us.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay by th'Mass, 'tis Witches.

Witches above.
Here this way, no that way, make haste, follow the Dame, we shall be too late, 'tis time enough; away, away, away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Wawnds and Flesh it is a flock of Witches byr Lady, they come reeght ore head, I'st let fly at 'em, hah, be th' mass I ha mamed one, heres one has a wing brocken at least.

div.stage:
He shoots,
M. Spencer
shrieks, and falls down.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p:
M. Spencer
by th' mass.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: O Rogues! I'le be revenged on you, Dogs, Villains, you have broken my Arm.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: I was made a Horse, a Titt by thee, by th' mass I'st be revenged o'thee.
sp.stage: He puts the Bridle upon her.
sp.l: Horse, Horse, be thou to me.
And carry me where e're I flee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O'ds Flesh, what's this? I connot believe my Sences; I mun walk home alone, but I'le charge my Peice again byr Lady, and the Haggs come agen I'st have t'other Shoot at 'em.

div.stage: The Scene returns to Sir Edwards House.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Dear Friend, I am so transported with excess of Joy, it is become a pain, I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Dear Bellfort! I am in the same Case, but (if the hope transports us so) what will Enjoyment do?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Blood is chill, and shivers when I think on't.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: One night with my Mistress would outweigh an Age of Slavery to come.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Rather than be without a nights Enjoyment of mine, I would be hang'd next morning: I am Impatient till they appear.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: They are Women of Honour, and will keep their Words; your Parson's ready, and three or four of our Servants for Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He is so, 'twill be dispatch'd in half a quarter of an hour, all are retired to bed.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Go in, yonders my Lady-Mother-in-Law coming, I must contrive a way to secure her: in, in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Death, that this old Fellow should be asleep already! she comes now to discover, what I know too well already.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: He is there I'le swear, a punctual Gentleman, and a person of much honour; Sir, I am come according to your appointment; Sir Ieffery is fast.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: 'Tis before I expected, Madam, I thought to have left Bellfort asleep, who is a Jealous man, and believes there is an Intrigue betwixt your Ladiship and me.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I vow: ha, ha, ha, me! no, no; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Retire for a short time, and when I have secured him, I'le wait on you; but let it be i'th' dark.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: You speak like a Discreet and Worthy Person, remember this Room, there's no body lies in it; I will stay there in the dark for you.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant. Well, I will go to the Ladies Chamber as if I ●istook it for mine, and let them know this is the time.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Dere is shometimes de pretty Wenches, doe walke here in de dark at night, and by my Shoulvaation if I doe catch one, I vill be after enjoying her Body: and fait and trot I have a great need too, it is a venial Sin, and I do not care.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Death, who is here? stay Ladies, here's the damn'd Priest in the way.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Go you, wee'l follow by and by in the dark.

div.stage: The Ladies retire, Doubty goes to his Chamber.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I hear one trampling, he is come already, sure Bellfort is asleep; who is there?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my Shoul it is a Womans speech, 'tis I; where are you? by my fait I vill maak a Child upon her Body.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Mr. Doubty.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Ay, let me put a sweet Kish upon dy hand Joy, and now I vill Shalute dy Mout, and I vill embraash dy Body too indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: S'life, I am mistaken, this is the Irish Priest; his understanding is sure to betray him.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I predee now Joy be not nishe, I vill maak shome good sport vid dee indeed.
sp.stage: La. pulls her hand away, and flies.
sp.l: Hoo now, phaare is dy hand now? oh,
sp.stage: Enter Mother Dickenson and puts her hand into the Priests.
sp.l: Here it is by my Shoule.
sp.p: I vill use dee braavely upon occaasion, I vill tell you, predee kish me upon my Faash now, it is a braave kish indeed.
By my Shoul don art very hansome, I doe know it, dough I cannot shee dee. I predee now retire vid me, aboo, aboo, by my Shoule dis is a Gaalant occaasion, come Joy.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this? he talked to some Woman, and kissed her too, and is retired into the Chamber I was in.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Every thing is quiet, I hear no noise.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Nor I, this is the happy time.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: This must be he; who's there?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: S'life! this is my Mothers voice, retire softly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh Misfortune! What makes her here? we are undone if she discovers us.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Whose there I say? will you not answer? what can this mean? 'tis not a Wench I hope for Doubty, and then I care not.
I am impatient till he comes; ha, whom have we here? I am sure this is not he, he does not come that way.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my shoul Joy, dou art a Gaalant peece of Flesh, a braave Bedfellow, phoo art dou?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: One that loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat vill I doe to shee dy faash I wonder? Oh, here is a light approaching unto us.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Who's this with a light? I must fly.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Now I vill shee dy faash.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: O, Sir, are you there? I am going to Mr. Smirk with this Candle poor man.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: O phaat have I done? Oh! de Vich! de Vich!

div.stage: The Witch sinks, she lets fall the Candle and Candle, and runs away shrieking.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! the Witch! the Witch!

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my Shoule I have had communicaation and Copulaation too vid a Succubus; Oh! phaat vill I do! phaat vill I do! by my fait and trot, I did tought shee had been a braave and gaallant Lady, and bee, oh! oh!

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: What shriek was that? hah! here's nobody, sure all's clear now!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I heard a shriek, this is the time to venture, they are frighted out of the Gallery, and all's clear now.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Let's venture; we shall have people stirring very early this morning to prepare for the Wedding else.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.l: Ha! who's that?
sp.stage: Isab. and Theo. creep softly into Bellforts and Doubty's Chamber.
sp.l: I am terribly afraid: Heaven!
what's this! the Chamber door open'd, and I saw a woman
〈◊〉 in, I am enraged, I'le distrub 'em.
sp.p:
Isabella, The dosia, Bellfort, Doubty
disguis'd, Parson and Servants in the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You see we are women of words, and women of courage too, that dare venture upon this dreadful business.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Welcom, more welcom than all the Treasures of the Sea and Land.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: More welcom than a Thousand Angels.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Death! we are undone, one knocks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Curse on 'em; keep the door fast.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Gentlemen open the door for Heavens sake, quickly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Open it, we are ruined else; wee'l into the Bed, you know what you have to do.

div.stage: They cover themselves. Enter La. Shacklehead.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the House is alarm'd with Witches, and I saw two come into this Chamber, and come to give you notice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here are none but whom you see.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: They come invisibly then; for we had our eyes on the door.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Are they not about the Bed somewhere? Let's search.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There are no Witches there, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Look a little, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Open the door quickly, quickly, the Witches are there.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh! my Husband, I am ruin'd if he sees me here.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p:
Put out the Candles,
He enters, and stumbles upon the Servant.
lye down before the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! I have broken my knees; this is the Witches doing: I have loast my Wife too: lights, lights there.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Ile not stay here.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Here's no staying for us.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Quickly, go by the Wall.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: For Heavens sake let's into the Gallery and call for lights.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Curse upon this Fellow and all ill luck.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Hell take him, the Ladies are gone too.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: WHat unfortunate disapointments have we met with!

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: All ill luck has conspired against us this night.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We have been near being discover'd, which would have ruin'd us.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: And we have but this night to do our business in; if we dispatch not this affair now, all will come out to morrow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I tremble to think on't; sure the surprise the Ladies were in before, has frighted 'em from attempting again.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I rather think that they have met with people, in the Gallery, that have prevented 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I reflect, I am apt to think so too; for they seem to be very hearty in this matter. Once more go to their Chamber.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Go you in then to ours.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Doubty.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: A Curse on all damn'd luck, is she here?

div.p: Sweet Madam, is it you! I have been watching, for Bellfort's sleeping ever since.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I venture hard, since Sir Ieffery miss'd me out of Bed, I had much a-do to ●asten an excuse upon him.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I am so affraid of Bellforts coming, Madam, he was here but even now: The hazard of your honour puts me in an Agony.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: O dear Sir, put out the Candle, and he can never discover any thing; besides, we will retire into you Room.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Death, what shall I do now.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: And since it is dark, and you cannot see my Blushes, I must tell you, you are a very ill guesser; for I my self was the person I discrib'd.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Oh Madam! you raille me, I will never believe it while I live; it is impossible.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I'le swear 'tis true: Let us withdraw into that Room, or we shall be discover'd.
Oh Heaven, I am undone, my Husband with a light run into your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Tis a happy deliverance.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I'le counterfeit walking in my sleep.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jeffery with a Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Where is this Wife of mine? She told me she fell asleep in the Closet, at her Prayers, when I mist her before; and I found her there at my coming back to my Chamber: But now she is not there I am sure. Ha! here she is. Ha, what is she blind! she takes no notice of me! how gingerly she treads!

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh! stand off— who's that would kill my dear Sir Ieffery? stand off I say.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Oh Lord, kill me! where! ha! here's nobody.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh! the Witch, the Witch, oh she pulls the cloaths off me. Hold me, dear Sir Ieffery, hold me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: On my Conscience and Soul she walks in her sleep.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh, all the Cloaths are off, cover me, oh I am so cold!

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Good lack a day, it is so! my Dear, my Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Hah, hah.

stage.hi: She opens her eyes and shrieks.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Wake I say, wake.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: 'Tis I my dear.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! Sir Ieffery, where am I?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Here in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh! how came I here?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Why, thou didst walk in thy sleep; good lack a day, I never saw the like.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: In my sleep say you! oh Heav'n! I have catcht my death. Let's to Bed, and tell me the story there.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Come on. Ha, ha, ha, this is such a jest! walk in your sleep! godsniggs, I shall so laugh at this in the morning.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: This is a happy come off.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: If we do not get into this Chamber suddenly, we are undone: They are up in the Offices already.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Never have adventures been so often disapointed, in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: There's no body in the Gallery now, we may go.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Hast then, and let us fly thither.

sp.speaker: Isab. Theo.
sp.p: Ah, what's this?

div.stage: Iust as they are entring, Chaplain and Susan enter with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! the Witches, the Witches.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Oh mercy upon us, where is this Candle?
So let me tell you, 'Twas no Witch; they were the two young Ladies, that frighted my dear beautious Love so; and I'le acquaint their Parents with it I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: This is strange, what could they have to do at this time o'th' night!

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: I know not. But I well know what I have to do. I am inflam'd beyond all measure, with thy heavenly beauty.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Alas, my beauty is but moderate; yet none of the worst, I must needs say.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: 'Tis blasphemy to say so; your eyes are bright like two Twin-Stars; your Face is an Ocean of beauty; and your Nose a Rock arising from it, on which my heart did split; Nothing but Ruby and Pearl is about thee; I must blazon thee by Jewels, thy beauty is of a Noble rank.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Good lack, what fine language is this! well, 'tis a rare thing to be a Schollar.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: 'Tis a miracle I should not think her hansome before this day; she is an Angel! Isabella is a Dowdy to her. You have an unexhausted mine of beauty. Dear Mrs. Susan cast thy Smiles upon me, and let me labour in thy Quarry: Love makes me Eloquent and Allegorical.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Sweet Sir, you oblige me very much by your fine Language; but I vow I understand it not: yet methinks it goes very prettily.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p:
I will unfold my hear unto thee; let me approach thy lip, Oh fragrant! fragrant!
Arabia felix
is upon this lip.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Ha! upon my lip, what's that? I have nothing, I have no pimple, nor any thing upon my lip, not I.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Sweet Innocence— I will be plain; I am inflam'd within, and would injoy thy lovely Body in sweet dalliance.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: How Sir! do you pretend to be a Divine, and would commit this sin! know, I will preserve my Honour and my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p:
Conscience? why so you shall, as long as our minds are united. The Casuists will tell you, it is a Marriage in
foro 〈◊〉▪
and besides, the Church of Rome allows Fornication: And truly it is much practis'd in our 〈◊〉 too. Let us retire, come, come.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Stand off, I defie you: your Casuists are Knaves, and you are a Papist, you are a foul voluptuous Swine, and I will never smile on you more. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Dear, beautious Creature, I am at thy mercy: Must I marry then? speak. Prethee spare me that, and I'le do any thing.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Stand off, I scorn thy Love; thou art a pitious Fellow.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Susan hear me; let us but do the thing, and then I'le marry thee.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I'le see thee hang'd e're I'le trust thee, or e're a Whoremaster of you all. No, I have been serv'd that trick too often already, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: Must I then Marry?

div.stage: Enter Isabella and Theodosia disguised, with Vizors like Witches.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yonder's the Chaplin and Susan;
But this disguise will fright 'em.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Let's on, we must venture.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Oh! the Witches, the Witches.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.l: Oh! fly, fly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What shriek was that?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.l: We have been several times alarm'd with these Noises.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Here's ●othing but madness and confusion in this Family.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Heav'n! who are these whispering?

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.l: Who's this I have hold on, heav'n grant it be not my Lady?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: 'Tis I, 'tis Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.l: 'Tis lucky— where is your fair Companion?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.l: And here's my Friend—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A thousand Blessings on you.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Phoo are dese?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Heav'n what's this, the damn'd Priest? These disguises will serve our turn yet: oh, Sir we are haunted with Witches here, run in quickly for some Holy-water.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I vill, I vill, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now in, in quickly.

div.stage: Ex. Bell. Doubt. Isab. and Theo.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaar is dese Vitches? phaar are dey? hah, dey are Wanisht for feare of me, I vill put dish down in dis plaash for my defence; what vill I do now? I have maade Fornication vid dis Vitch or Succubus indeed; when I do go home, I vill be after being absolv'd for it, and den I vill be as Innocent as de child unborne by my Shoule. I have hangd my self all round vid reliques indeed, and de Sprights and de Vitches cannot hurt me fait and trot.—

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: My Dear, I come to visit thee again.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat is here, de Vitch agen does come to haunt me, Benidi●●●e, out upon dee dou damn'd Vitch, vat dosht dou come upon me for? I defy dee, a plaague taak dee indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: I am no Witch, I am a poor Innocent woman, and a Tenant of Sir Edwards, and one that loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Dou plaagy Vitch, let me come unto my holy vater, and I vill pay dee off indeed; hoh, by my shoulvaation 'tis all flown away— oh dou damnd Vitch, I vill hang dee indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: Pretdee be kinder, my Dear, and kiss me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Out, out, kiss dee— a plaague taake dee Ioy▪ stand off upon me, by my shoulvaation, I vill kiss de dogs Arse shaving dy presence, before I vill be after kishing dee.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: Be not so unkind to thy own Dear. Thou didst promise me Marriage, thou know'st, and I come to claim thee for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Aboo, boo, boo, Marriage, Vat vill I Marry vid a Vitch, by my shoule—
Conjuro te, fuge, fuge.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: Do not think to put me off with your Latine; for do you hear Sir, you promised me Marriage, and I will have you.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Oh phaat vill I do? Vat vill I do?

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: This Morning I will Marry you, I'le stay no longer, you are mine.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: By my shoule Joy I vill tell you, I am a Romish Priest, and I cannot Maarry. What would you have now?

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: You shall turn Protestant then, for I will have you.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
By St. Paatrick phaat does she say? Oh damn'd Protestant Vitch. I vill speak shivilly, Madam, I vill tell dee now, if dou vill repair unto dine own House, by my shoulwaation I vill come unto dee to morrow, and I vill give dee satisfaaction indeed.
Aside,
As soon as she does get home, fait and trot I vill bring de Constable, and hang her indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: I'le not be put off, Ile have you now.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: By my Shoul I vill not go, I vill hang dee for a Vitch; and now I do apprehend dee upon daat. Help, help.
I have taaken a Vitch ineeed: Help, help.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: I am your Wife.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Help, help, I have taaken a Vitch.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Ha! what's here? one of the Witches by th'Mess.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Ay, by my Shoule Ioy, I have taaken her.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Nay, byr Lady, whoo has taken yeow by yeowr leave.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: We han taken a Witch too; lay hawd on her.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.l: Deber, Deber, little Martin, little
Martin, where art thou little
Master? where art thou little Master?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Dost dou mutter? By my shoule I vill hang dee Ioy; a plaague taak dee indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: Thou art a Popish Priest, and I will hang thee.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I am Innocent as the Child unborn, I vill taak de Oades, and bee—

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p:
Marmot, Mamilion, Rouncy, Puckling,
little Master, have you left me all?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: We han got another Witch, who's strongly gaurded and Watched i'th stabo.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Come let's hale her thether: We cou'd not get into the hawse till naw, we came whoame so late at night.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Come let us taake de Vitch away: I vill hang dee Joy— a plaague taake dee fait.

sp.speaker: M. Dick.
sp.p: Am I o'retaken then— I am Innocent, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Let us carry her thether, come along.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Pull her away— we will be after hanging of you Fait and Trot.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, and Servant, with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I could not rest to night for the Joy of being Marryed to day: 'Tis a pretty Rogue— she's somewhat Cross— but I warrant her she will love me, when she has tryed me once.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why would you rise so soon? 'Tis not day yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I cannot sleep man, I am to be Married Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ay, and therefore you should have slept now, that you might watch the better at night: For 'twill be uncivil to sleep much upon your Wedding Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Uncivil, ay that it will— very uncivil: I wont sleep a wink. call my new Brother-in-Law: Oh here he is, he can't sleep neither.

div.stage: Enter Harfo●● and his Man with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Set down the Candle; and go bid the Groom get the Horses ready, I must away to the Powts.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Brother, good morrow to you; what a Devil's this— what booted! are you taking a Journey upon your wedding day?

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: No, but I will not lose my Hawking this Morning; I will come back time enough to be Married Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, breeding's a fine thing— this is a strange ill-bred Fellow! what Hawk upon your Wedding day! I have other game to fly at— Oh how I long for night— why my Sister will think you care not for her.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p:
aside,
No more— I don't very much ● a pox on Marrying, I love a Hawk, and a Dog, and a Horse, better than all the Women in the World.
[To him.
Why I can Hawk and Marry too: She shall see I love her: For I will leave off Hawking before Ten a Clock.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot come at the Horses, for the People have taken a brace of Witches, and they are in the stable under a strong guard, that will let no body come at 'em.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Uds flesh, I shall have my Horses bewitch'd, and lose 500 Pounds worth of Horse Flesh.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, no, they can do no hurt— when they are taken the Devil leaves 'em— Let's go see 'em—

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: What shall we do?

div.stage: Their men taking up the Candles, 〈◊〉 Spirits fly away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Let us stand up close against the Wall.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Listen, here are the Witches, what will become of us?

div.stage:
Enter
Isabella, Theodosia, Bellfort
and Doubty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Thousand blessings light on thee my Dear Pretty Witch.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: O Lord! there's the Devil too Courting of a Witch.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: This is the first Night I ever liv'd, thou Dearest, Sweetest Creature.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Oh! sweet quoth a, that's more than I can say of my self at this time.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: We will go and be decently prepared for the Wedding that's Expected:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Not a word of discovery till the last; creep by the Wall. Ha— who's here!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Oh good Devil don't hurt us, we are your humble servants.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In▪ in quickly—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Lights, Lights, Help, Help, Murder, Murder, Oh good Devil dont hurt me; I am a Whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: And I am a Drunkard; Help, Help, Murder.

div.stage:
Enter
Tom. Shacklehead
with a Candle, and Tegue O. Devilly.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Phaat is de matter Joy?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: O Nuncle! here have been Devils and Witches: They have flown away with our Candles, and put us in fear of our lives.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Here's a great Storm Arising— what can be the matter! the Haggs are at Warck by'r Lady, and they come to me by'th' mass, I ha getten my brawd Sward: Ay●● mow 'em down, ged faith will I.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Be not affraid, I vill taake a Caare, and I vill conjure down this Tempest fait an bee.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Flesh that Thunder Clap shook the hawse, Candle burns blew too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Death, it goes out, what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: An the Witches come, by'r Lady Ayst mow 'em down with my brawd Sward I warrant o'— I have shot one Witch ●lying to Neeght already.

div.stage:
Enter
M. Hargrave, M. Madge
, and two Witches more; they mew and spit like Cats, and fly at 'em, and scratch 'em.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: What's this! we are set upon by Cats.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: They are Witches in the shape of Cats, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Phaat will I do? Cat, Cat, Cat, Oh, oh.
Conjuro vos fugite, fugite. Cacodaem●nes, Cats, Cats.

div.stage: They Scrat●h all their Faces till the Blood runs about 'em. He cuts at them.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Have at ye all, I ha Mauld some of 'em by'th' mass, they are fled, but I am plagneily scratcht.

div.stage: The Witches screek and run away.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Dey ware affraid of my Charmes, and de sign of de Cross did maake dem fly— but d●y have scratcht a great deale upon my faash for all daat.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Mine is all of a gore blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And mine too— that th●s● damn'd Witches should disfigure my Countenance upon my Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: O Lord, what a Tempest's this?

div.stage: Enter Sir Jeffery with a Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Heaven! What a Storm is this! The Witches and all their Imps are at work. Who are these? hah!— your Faces are all bloody.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: We have been frighted out of our Wits; we have been assaulted by Witches in the shape of Cats, and they have scratcht us most ruefully.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: But I did fright dem away, by my Shoule.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Why you are as much mauld as any one, nay, they are at work— I never remember such Thunder and Lightning; bid 'em ring out all the Bells at the Church.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
I vill
*
* Wier: praest. Daem. lib. 1. p. 43. and 44. shows, that it is the opinion of Papists, that Baptized Bells will drive away Tempests, see also
Guacc. compend. malisiearum. lib. 3. cap.
6.
Baptize all your Bells for you Joy, and then they vill stop the Tempest indeed, and not before; I tell you, oh, Baptized Bells are braave things fait.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Flesh, Christen Bells!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, I believe the great Bell at Oxford was Christen'd Tom.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: And that at Lincoln has a Christen name too.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: I tell de Joy, I vill carry de hosht and shome reliques abroad, and we vill get a black Chicken and maak one of de Vitches throw it into de Aire, and it vill maak stop upon de Tempest.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p:
Why, all the Authors say,
*
*
Nider in formicario
cites this from a Judge, who had it from the confession of a Witch. cap. 4.
sacrificing a black Chicken so, will raise a Tempest.

sp.speaker: Tho. Sha.
sp.p: What's here a haund! uds Flesh, you see I have cut off a haund of one of the Haggs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Let's see, this is a lucky evidence; keep it and see what Witch it will fit, and 'tis enough to hang her.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
The Storm begins to stay; I did shay shome Aves, and part of de Gospd of St. Iohn, and in fine,
fugiat Tempestas
, and it does go away upon it indeed.

sp.speaker: Tho. Sha.
sp.p: We may trace her by her Blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But hark you, What's the reason my Hawks wanted their Pidgeons: uds bud I shall remember you for it; you think to live like a Lubber here and do nothing.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Peace, I was drunken, peace good Sir Timothy, Ayst do no more so.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Methinks all on a sudden the Storm is laid.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Constable and the rest of us have taken the whole flock of Witches: but they fell upon us like Cats first; but we have beaten 'em into Witches, and now we have 'em fast.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: So now, their Power's gone when they are taken, let's go see 'em.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: I'le wash my face and away a Hawking, now the Storm's over, 'tis broad day.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I will call up Sir Edward; Musick, and wake the two Brides with a Serenade this morning.

div.stage: Enter Sir Edward and his man with a Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
It has been a dreadful Storm, and strangely laid o'th' suddain, this is a ioyful day to me: I am now in hopes to strengthen and preserve my Family— my poor Daughter has the worst on't, but she is discreet; and will mould Sir Timothy to what she pleases: he is good natur, ●, and he loves her, and his Estate's beyond Exception.— Go call my Son to me, bid him rise, 'tis day, put out the Candle now.
Ex. Servant.
This Son, I out of Duty must provide for; for there's a Duty from a Father to make what he begets as happy as he can; and yet this Fool makes me unhappy as he can: but that I call Philosophy to my aid, I could not bear him.
How now, your Face scrach't! what were you drunk last night, and have been at Cuffs?

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p:
No, Sir Timothy, I, and
Tegue O Devilly
, and
Tom. Shaklehead
were assaulted by Witches in the Shapes of Cats; and
Tom. Shaklehead
has cut off one of the Cats hands; and all the Witches are taken, and are in the Stable under a strong Guard.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: What foolish wild story is this? you have been drunk in Ale, that makes such foggy Dreams.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Sbud Sir, the story is true, you'l find it so.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: How now! what makes you booted upon your Wedding-day?

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Why, I am going a Hawking this morning, and I'le come home time enough to be marry'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Thou most incorrigible Ass, whom no precept or example can teach common sence to, that would have made thee full of Joy at thy approaching happines; it would have filld thy mind, there could have been no room for any other obiect; to have a good Estate setled upon thee, and to be married to a woman of that Beauty, and that Wit and Wisdom, I have not known her equal, would have transported any one but such a clod of Earth as thou art: thou art an excrement broken from me, not my Son.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Why Sir, I am transported; but can't one be transported with Hawking too? I love it as I love my life, would you have a Gentleman neglect his sports?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: None but the vilest men will make their sports their business; their books, their friends, their kindred and their country should concern 'em: such drones serve not the ends of their Creation, and should be lopt of from the rest of men.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: A man had better dye than leave his sport; tell me of books, I think theres nothing in 'em for my part; and for Musick I had as live set in the stocks, as hear your fine songs; I love a Bagpipe well enough, but there's no Musick like a ●●eep Mouth'd Hound.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
Thou most excessive blockhead, thou art enough to imbitter all my sweets; thou art a Wen belonging to me, and I shall do well to cut thee off: but do you hear Fool,
go and dress your self, and wait upon your Bride, or by Heaven I will disinherit you. This is the Critical day, on which your happiness or misery depends; Think on that.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Was ever so devilish a Father to make one neglect one's sport, because he's no sports-man himself; A Pox on Marrying, could not I Hawk and Marry too? well I am resolv'd I'le steal out after I am Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come on: Place your selves just by her Chamber and play— and sing that Song I love so well.

div.l: My Dear, my sweet, and most delicious Bride
Awake, and see thine own Dear waiting at thy Dore;
Surely she cannot sleep for thinking of me, poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Isabela
sp.p:
above.
Who's this disturbs my rest! is it thou? I thought 'twas some Impertinent Coxcomb or other; dost thou hear, carry away that scurvy Face from me as soon as possibly thou canst.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, you have a pleasant way with you, you'l never leave your pretty humors, I see that.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Ha! Thou hast been scratching with Wenches, was not thy face ugly enough, but thou must disfigure it more than Nature has done? one would have thought that had don't enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Faith thou art a pretty wag, Thou It never leave thy Roguery; Wenches, why 'twas done by Witches, who in the shape of Cats, had like to have kil'd us: your Brother, my Uncle, and the Irish man are all as bad as I.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Prethee begon, and mend thy Face, I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it's no matter, I'le come into thy Chamber, I must be familiar with you—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And I will be very free with you; you are a Nauseous Fool and you shall never come into my Chamber. ●S life, would your begin you Reign before you are Marry'd? no, I'le dominere now— begon.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, faith I'le not leave you so, you little Cross Rogue you; open the dore there, let me in, let me in I say.

div.stage: Theodosia comes out in a Weitches habit and a Viz●r.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Who's that? Thou art my love, come into my arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh the Witch! the Witch! help,

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Ieffery, Lady, Tegue O Devilly, Tom. Shacklehead, Clod,
and Sir
Iefferies Clerk.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: So, Now thou art come, my Dear, I'le dispatch the Witches, they are all taken and Guarded in the stable: Clod, bid 'em bring em all hither.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: That's well, are they caught? let 'em come before us, we will order 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: I would do nothing without thee my Dear.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Here Lady Taake some
1
1 Mall. Malif. I●stitor Springer,
Part 3. Quest 15. A caution to the Judges,
Secum deferant sal exercizatum in Dominica die palmarum & herbas benedictas, He enim res insimul cum cera benedicta in voluta & in collo deporta●a, &c. miram habent efficatiam, &c. [
I have made my
Irish
man translate the
Latin
false on purpose
.
Conjur'd shalt and put upon dee and palme, and shome Holy-Wax daat I did bring for dish occaasion, and de Witches will not hurt dy Laadyship.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
I did give dy Husband shome before Joy, but I will speak a word unto you all, let every one
2
2 For spitting in their Bosoms, see
Tibullus, Eleg. 2. Ter Cano ter dictis desp●e carminibus.
] And in
Eleg. 1. Despuit in molles & sibi quisque sinus.
This Theocritik mentions,
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
, and several other Authors, particularly
Theophrastus libro de characterismis
, speaking of superstitious persons:
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
, for they thought they that were mad, or bad the Falling-sickness, were possessed with Devils.
spit three times upon deir Boshomes, and Cross d●mselves, it is braave upon dis occaasion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Daat is very well now.

Let no Vitch
3
3 Mal. Mallif. part 3. quest. 15. Non permittant se ab ea tangi corporaliter. Id. 〈◊〉. Et si comode fieri potest ipsa a tergo deorsu●● vertendo adiudices & assessores introducatur.
touch no part about you, and let 'em come vid deir Arshes before deir Faashes, phen dey come to Confession or Examinaation. We have eye-biting Witches in
Eerland▪
that kill vid deir Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: This is a very Learned and Wise man.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: He is a great man indeed, we are nothing to him.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: You vill shee now, now I will speak unto dem, here dey come; I shay bring their Arshes before deir Faashes.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: Bring 'em backward, thus.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p:
You Clod, and you
Tom. Shacklehead
have sworn sufficiently against the Witch Spencer, and so has that Country Fellow.

sp.speaker: M. Spen.
sp.p: I am an Innocent Woman, and they have broken my arm with a shot, Rogues, Villains, Murderers.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Dey are angry, daat is a certain sign of a Vitch; and dey cannot cry,
4
4 Boain and several Authors mention this; but Mal. Malef. particularly Part 3. Quest. 15. p. 557. Hoc enim pro certissimo signo, &c. quod etiamsi ad Lacrimandum conjurationibus hortetur aliqua & compellatur (and the Inquisitors have an Office for this, as you will see in the Flagellum daemonum per Fr. Ieron, Menguem. in the 2. Tome of Mal. Malef.) sed si Malefica existit Lachrymas emittere non potest, dabit quidem flebiles & ex sputo genas & oculos linire &c. Having of Biggs and Teats all modern Witchmongers in England affirm. The cutting off the hand is an old story.
daat is anoder shine; look to 'em dey doe not put spittle upon deir Faashes to maake beleife daat dey do weep: Yet Bodin dosh shay, daat a Vitch can cry three drops vid her right Eye, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Have you searcht 'em all as I bid you Woman?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Yes an't please your Worship, and they have all great Biggs and Teates in many parts, except Mother Madge, and hers are but small ones.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: It is enough, make their Mittimus, and send 'em all to Goal.

sp.speaker: Witches.
sp.l: I am Innocent, I am Innocent,
Save my life, I am no Witch,
I am Innocent, save my life.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Ven dey do shay dey are Innocent, and deshire to shave deir lives, 'tis a shertain shigne of a Vitch fait and trot.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p:
Besides, this Woman
Margaret Demdike
by name, threatned to be revenged on me, and my Cow has been suckt dry ever since, and my Child has had fits.

sp.speaker: M. Demd.
sp.p: She lies, she lies, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: This is she that had a hand cut off, it fits her to a hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Tis enough: Tis enough.

sp.speaker: M. Harg.
sp.p: Must I be hang'd for having my hand cut off? I am Innocent, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Constak.
sp.p: Did not you say to my Wife you would be reveng'd on me? and has not she been struck with pain in her rump-bone ever since? and did not my Sow cast her farrow last Night?

sp.speaker: Harg.
sp.p: You should send your Brother to Goal for cutting my hand off.

sp.speaker: Tom. Sha.
sp.p: What for cutting a Cats hand off? you were a Cat when I cut it off.

sp.speaker: Tho. O. Georges.
sp.p: An't please your Worship this Woman, Gamer Dickinson, Who threped: and threped, and aw to becaw'd me last Neeght i'th' Lone, and who said he woud be reveng'd on me; and this Morning at four a Clock Butter would not come, nor the Ale warck a bit, who has bewicht it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: I have heard enough, send 'em all to the Goal.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: You must never give a Witch any Milk, Butter, Cheese, or any thing that comes from the Cows.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Now dou damn'd Vitch, I vill be after sheeing dee hang'd indeed, I did taake her by my shoule—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I am a poor Innocent Woman, I am abused, and I am his wife an't please your worship: He had knowledg of me in a Room in the Gallery, and did promise me Marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Hah! what's this?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
By my Shalvaation I am innocent as de Child unborn, I speak it before Heav'n, I did never make fornicaation in my life.
Aside.
Vid my Nostrills: dere is a mental reservaation, I am too subtil for dem, indeed gra.
To them
. It is malice upon me.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: There is something in this story, but I dare not speak of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p:
I do believe you Mr.
O Devilly
.

sp.speaker: Dicken.
sp.p: Besides, he is a Popish Priest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Aboo, boo, boo, a Priest, I vill taake de Oades Fait and trot; I did never taake. Holy Orders since I was bore.
Aside.
In Iamaica. Dere is anoder Mentall reservaation too; and it is Lawful.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I have been told he is a Popish Priest, and has been at Rome.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
I speak it in de presence of all de Saints, daat I never did see Rome in all my life, Vid de eyes of a Lyon,
Aside.
Dere was anoder by my shoule.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p:
Take away the Witches, there is their Mittimus, carry 'em all to
Lancaster. Witches
. I am Innocent, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Come on you Hags, now your Master the Devil has left you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Sir you must excuse me, I must give you the Oathes upon this Information.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: And by my shoule Joy, I will taak dem and twenty or thirty more Oades if dou dosht please indeed, I vill take 'em all to serve dee, Fait and Trot.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Come into the Hall, there's the Statute Book.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: I will go in and see if the Brides be Ready.

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Edward, Bellfort
and Doubty.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Gentlemen, This day I am to do the great Duty of a Father in providing for the Settlement of my Children; this day we will dedicate to Mirth, I hope you will partake with me in my Joy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I should have had a greater share in any Joy that could affect so worthy a man, had not your Daughter been the only Person, I ever saw, whom I could have fixt my love upon; but I am unhappy that I had not the honour to know you till it was to late.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: This had been a great honour to me, and my Daughter, and I am sorry I did not know it sooner, and assure you it is some trouble upon me.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: How like a Gentleman he takes it, but I have an Ass, Nay two, to deal with.

div.stage:
Enter
Lady Shacklehead
, and Isabella, and Theodosia.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Good morrow Brother, our brace of Brides are ready, where are the lusty Bridegrooms?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Heav'n grant this may prove a happy day.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Mr. Doubty, was ever such an unlucky Night as we have had.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: 'Tis happy to me who was assur'd of the love of one, I love much more than all the Joys on Earth.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Now you make me blush, I swear it is a little too much.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ladies, I wish you much joy of this day.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Much happiness to you.

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Ieffery, and Tegue O Devilly.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Brother, good morrow to you; This is a happy day, our families will soon be one: I have sent all the Witches to the Goal.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Had you Evidence enough?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Ay, too much; this Gentleman was accused for being a Papist and a Priest, and I have given him the Oathes, and my Certificate, and on my Conscience he is a very good Protestant.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: It is no matter, I did taak de Oades, and I am a very good Protestant upon occasion, Fait.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Say you so? between you and I, how many Sacraments are there?

sp.speaker: Priest,
sp.p:
How many? by my shoule dere are sheven; how many would would dere be ●ink
you Hob? by my shoule I have a dispensaation, indeed I am t●o 〈◊〉 for 'em fait I am.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: So here are the Bridegrooms.

div.stage:
Enter Sir Timothy, and Yo.
Harfort, Servant
.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh my Dear pretty Bride, let me kiss thy hand, how joyful am I, that I shall have my Dear within these arms! ah! now the little Rogue can smile upon me.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: Cousin good morrow to you, I am glad to see you, how do you do this Morning?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Never better.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: God be thanked, I am very glad on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Is not the Parson come yet?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he is very busy at his Breakfast in the buttery: And as soon as he has finisht his Pipe and his Tankard— he will wait on you: he has Marry'd one Cupple already, The Chaplin and Mrs. Susan.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I am sorry for't, that Chaplin is a Rascal— I have found him out, and will turn him away—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here are some of your Tennants and Country men come to be merry with you, and have brought their Piper and desire to daunce before you.

div.stage:
Enter several Tennants, and
Ccuntry Fellows
.

sp.speaker: Tennants.
sp.p: We are come to wish your Worship, my Young Master and Lady Joy of this happy day.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: You are kindly welcom Neighbours, this is happiness indeed, to see my Friends, and all my loving Neighbours thus about me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heavens bless your good Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: These honest men are the strength and sinnews of our Country; such men as these are uncorrupted, and while they stand to us we fear no Papists, nor French invasion; this day we will be merry together.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ayst make bold to Daunce for joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
Prethee do—
Clod Dances.
Go bid the Parson come in, we will dispatch this business here before you all.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Hold, there needs no Parson.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: We are Marry'd already, and desire your blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: It is impossible.

div.stage: Bell. Doubt. Isab. and Theo. kneel.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Heav'n! what's this I see?

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Theives! Robbers! Murderers of my honour, I'le hang that Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: What pageantry is this? explain your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a Devil do they mean now!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The truth is Sir, we are Marry'd; we found you Fathers were too far ingag'd to break off: I 〈◊〉 forced us to this way, and nothing else can be a fit excuse.

sp.speaker: Smerk.
sp.p: We have designed this ever since last Summer, and any other but a private way, had certainly prevented it. Let excess of love excuse our fault, Sir Ieffery, I will exceed what s●tlement was made upon your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: An! I will, Sir, do the same Right to yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Flesh and Heart— I'le Murder her.
Hold Sir, she is mine now; I beseech you moderate your passion.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Oh vile Creature; I'le tear her Eyes out.
Forbear good Madam: What cannot be redrest must be past by—

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: Thou worst of Theives, thou knowest I can ne're pass it by.

sp.speaker: Sir Ieff.
sp.p: Sir Edward, you may do what you will, but I'le go in and meditat● revenge.

sp.speaker: La. Sha.
sp.p: And I—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, hold me, I am bloody minded, and shall commit Murder else; my honour, my honour, I must kill him, hold me fast, or I shall kill him.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: For my part Cousin, I wish you Joy, for I am resolved to hunt and hawk, and course as long as I live—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Cruel Woman, I did not think you would have serv'd me so; I shall ●un mad, and hang my self and walk.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Now phaar is de soleedity of all dish— phy all ish paasht▪ and what vil you say now? You must taak shome Consolaation unto you— Dou must Fornicaate vid dy Moders Maid sharvants; and daat is all one by my shoule.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Hold, Gentlemen, who Marry'd you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Gentleman, who is under his gray Coat, my Parson.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: 'Tis something unhospitable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope Sir, you'l not have cause to repent it; had there been any other way for me to have escap't perpetual misery, I had not taken this.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: But you Sir have most Iniurd me.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: I beg a thousand pardons, Tho' I must have perisht if I had not done it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: It is no injury Sir, I never could have lov'd your Son; we must have been unhappy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And I had been miserable with Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Yo. Har.
sp.p: To say truth, I did not much care for her neither, I had rather not marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: Eternal Blockhead! I will have other means to preserve my Name: Gentlemen, your are men of ample Fortunes and worthy Families— Sir I wish you happiness with my Daughter, take her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You have given me more than my own Father did, then life and fortune.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You are the best of Fathers and of men.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: I will endeavour to appease Sir Ieffery and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Doubt.
sp.p: Your are Generous beyond expression Sir.

sp.speaker: Chaplin.
sp.p: Sir, I hope your Worship will pardon me, I am Marry'd to Mrs. Susan.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: You are a Villain, that has made love to my Daughter, and corrupted my Son.

sp.speaker: Chap.
sp.p: Have they told all, I am ruin'd? good Sir, continue me your Chaplin, and I will Do and Preach whatever you command me.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p:
I'le not have a Divine with so flexible a Conscience, there shall be no such Vipers in my Family; I will take care you never shall have Orders. But she has serv'd me well, and I will give her a Farm of
40. l. per annum
to Plow: Go Sir, it was an Office you were born to.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Did I not bid de Fornicaate? and dou didst Marry Joy; if dou hadst not maade Marriage, I vould have maade dee a Catholick, and preferred dee to Saint
Omers, Dey should have bred dee for one of deir Witnesses fait.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I must beg your pardon Sir, I have a warrant against this
Kelly, Alias Tegue O Devilly
— he is accus'd for being in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.p: My house is no refuge for Traytors Sir.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Aboo, boo, boo! by my shalvaation dere is no Plot, and I vill not go vid you. Dou art a damn'd Fanaatick, if dou dosht shay dere is a Plot. Dou art a Presbiterian Dogg.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: No striving, come a long with me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
Phaat vil I do: I am Innocent as de Child dat is to be Born; and if they vill●hang me, I vill be a shaint indeed.
My hanging Speech was made for me, long a go by de Iesuits, and I have it ready, and I vill live and dy by it, by my shoule.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I charge you in the Kings Name assist me.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, I wish you both the happiness you deserve.
How shallow is our foresight and our prudence!
Be ne're so wise, design what e're we will
There is a Fate that over-rules us still.

div.head: EPILOGUE, By Mrs. BARRY and TEGUE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Barry.
sp.l: A Skilful Mistriss uses wondrous Art,
To keep a pevish crazy Lovers Heart,
His awkard Limbs forgetful of Delights,
Must be urg'd on by Tricks and Painful Nights:
Which the poor Creature is content to bear,
Fine Manteau's and new Petticoats to wear.
And Sirs, your sickly Appetites to raise,
Yhe starving Players try a thousand ways.

Tou had a
Spanish Fryer
of Intrigue,
And now we have presented you a Tegue;
Which with much cost from Ireland we have got,
If he be dull, e'en hang him for the Plot.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.l: Now have a care, for by my Shoul shalwaation.
Dish vill offend a Party in de Naation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Barry.
sp.l: They that are angry must be very Beasts,
For all Religions laugh at foolish Priests.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.l: By Creesh, I swear, de Poet has undone me,
Some simple Tory vill maake beat upon me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Barry.
sp.l: Good Protestants, I hope you will not see,

A Martyr made of our poor
Tony Leigh
.
Our Popes and Fryers on one side offend,
And yet alas the City's not our Friend:
The City neither like us nor our Wit.

They say their Wives learn ogling in the Pit.
*
* A foolish word amongthe Canters for glancing.
They'r from the Boxes taught to make advances,
To answer stolen Sighs and naughty Glances.
We Vertuous Ladies some new way must seek,
For all conspire our playing Trade to break.
If the bold Poet freely shows his Vein,
In every place the snarling tops complain,
Of your gross follies if you will not hear,
With inoffensive Nonsense you must bear.
You, like the Husband, never shall receive,
Half the delight the sportful Wife can give.
A Poet dares not whip this foolish Age,
You cannot bear the Physick of the Stage.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
